Horribly studio-bound, there is nothing that distinguishes this as a film. It is void of everything that made the show an exciting stage experience. Many of the sets, look like sets, and the make-up, hairstyles and many of the costumes on the women is very 1960's and silly looking for 1912. Eliza Doolittle is the heart and soul of this musical, but Audrey Hepburn's performance of her is so false, that the very life of the show is gone. She's all wide-eyes and and inappropriate smiles (watch the LOVERLY number), with carefully placed smudges. She growls and clenches her fists when she's supposed to; but it just ends up being Audrey Hepburn play acting at being Eliza. She never, ever makes you think she IS Eliza. Also, her accent is wrong. She would never have fooled anyone, with her "European" sounding English accent. The dubbing of Miss Hepburn (done after the film was made), is almost as bad as watching a "Godzilla" movie. It always looks out of sync, and never sounds right. When one remembers Broadway's original Eliza, Julie Andrews (who should have been in this film), it makes Hepburn's casting even harder to take. Rex Harrison and the supporting cast are first rate; but it is Eliza who must be perfect, and she isn't. Hepburn's miscasting, Cukor's plodding direction, and the failure to recognize that they were making a film, make this a disappointment of the highest degree. NOT recommended!

DVD runtime: 170 min. (Intermisssion about 2/3rds through). The film is a version of Lerner & Loewe's 1956 Broadway musical which, in turn, was a musical adaptation of George Bernard Shaw's 1916 play "Pygmalion." (Shaw's play loosely draws on Ovid's 1st century "Metamorphoses" for its plot.) Shaw was very active throughout his professional life in attacking the English class system (based very much on language & accent, as well as women's subservient role). "MFL" is in Ebert's list of "Great Films." Years ago, I bought the record album of "MFL" and the sequence of its music tells the rough outlines of the story: a financially secure, snobbish, completely non-empathic but gifted phonetics professor, Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) makes a bet with a close friend, Col. Pickering, that within 6 months he can transform Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn), a Cockney girl selling flowers, a "gutter snipe," into a lady who'll be accepted by and in upper society by changing the way she speaks. The movie shows that next 6 months as Eliza learns "proper" (i.e., upper class) speech and manners. Harrison & Holloway (the latter plays Eliza's father) reprise their roles from the Broadway musical. Hepburn's Cockney accents seemed genuine; she lip synchs her songs to Marni Nixon's actual vocals. Roger Ebert's helpful review discusses in detail the huge uproar from the choice of Hepburn instead of Julie Andrews (who played Eliza's role on Broadway), the substitution of Nixon's singing voice, and the fate of lip synching after that (plus many other interesting things). This gorgeous, stunning film adds more verses and variations to the music than that on my album. Harrison and Hepburn are simply great in their roles, as are all other supporting players including a much younger Jeremy Brett (later an older Sherlock Holmes in the PBS series) as Eliza's young aristocratic suitor, Freddy, smitten with Eliza.All the sets are magnificent. My companion had seen stage versions of "MFL" twice before but never this film -- she found the film was much richer and more satisfying. I was roughly familiar with the story but surprised to learn some things I hadn't known from the songs on the album: e.g., that Prof. Higgins had a near disastrous practice run with Eliza at the Ascot races and that something unwanted happened to Eliza's father that elevated him into the middle class.My rating is 10 of 10 stars. My only minor criticism is that I thought both of the Doolittle (Holloway) singing and dancing numbers, "With a Little Bit 'o Luck" & "Get Me to the Church on Time," went on a little too long (half would've been sufficient for me). The film nicely leaves one in doubt as to whether Eliza will go back to and stay with Higgins or marry Freddy--although maybe with a slight bias to returning to Higgins? In case you wonder what happens to Eliza in GBS's "Pygmalion" you can read Shaw's own long description of their later lives (see 'Sequel: What Happened Afterwards') following Act V (for the link, google: bartleby: Shaw, Bernard 1916 Pygmalion). And, in that same link, if you also read the 'Preface: A Professor of Phonetics,' you'll find that Shaw somewhat modeled Higgins' personality and interactions after an actual professor of phonetics, Henry Sweet, who was gifted but quite prickly --and/or, read the entire delightful "Pygmalion" play.

Lumbering,overlong musical based on the Broadway hit,which in turn was based on Shaw's play.Major assets: the lavish costumes and Harrison's on-target performance.Major flaws: the too-stagey sets,the irrelevant musical numbers involving Hepburn's father, and Hepburn herself,who is,in the first part,utterly unconvincing (later she improves).The 1938 "Pygmalion" is too talky but still better.

My Fair Lady is tops.  It's hard to think of any way the film could be improved.  Just leave it as it is, don't worry about 'political correctness' and enjoy yourself.  You'll be humming the show tunes for weeks.

I'm not much of a fan of movie musicals. I mainly took a chance on this one because I knew that it was an influence on Seth MacFarlane of Family Guy fame, specifically in terms of the creation of the Stewie Griffin character. Now, having watched the movie, I am very glad that I did.Musically, the film is exceptional. There's no shortage of memorable melodies and all are augmented with clever lyrics. There are no throwaway songs, either. Whenever a character segues into song it is always relevant to the storyline.Likewise, the acting is top-notch. This is the role that Rex Harrison was born to play. Ditto Stanley Holloway. Audrey Hepburn is exquisite. I could go on but I'd end up listing just about everyone who had more than a few lines.The visuals are breathtaking. Among others, the movie won Oscars for Best Art Direction-Set Decoration, Best Cinematography, Best Costume Design & Best Director, all of which were well-deserved.At the core of all of this is a compelling storyline that fills nearly three hours with ease. Outwardly, the film is a 'Cinderella story' though the script is rife with subtle commentary on class distinctions. However, the ending may put off some since it is deliberately vague. I don't think that there's a right answer to the question "What happens next?", though others are more than willing to jump to conclusions.To sum it up, this movie is proof of the old adage "They don't make 'em like they used to".

Hepburn's Eliza is the only complaint myself and I hope many critics have with this film. Not casting Julie Andrews in a revival of her stage performance is downright asinine. As for the rest of the film, it is simply lovely. The opening is enchanting, filled with the richness of Lerner and Loewe's wonderful score. Harrison is dead solid perfect as irascible Henry Higgins. No one can ever play that role better again. \ At first viewing, it may last too long for some, but you are enthralled by the work so much that you don't care. You want more! I do to. I just want it with Julie Andrews.

reviews.review_title: Delightful to watch but the ending doesn't work. Some scenes need to be tightened up.
reviews.content: While watching this film it is a extremely engaging delightful musical comedy that pokes fun at men trying to create the ideal woman and the underlying sexism of that. The film is smart enough to know that Henry Higgins is a jerk and mocks him almost as much as he mocks Eliza. "Just you wait Henry Higgins" does a lot of work to make sure Higgins' appalling behavior is contextualized correctly. Unfortunately, the film loses its nerve and inexplicably has Eliza return to him at the end for a conventional romantic ending. This choice (not shared by the Shaw play) undermines and make s the previous 3 hours to think about in context. Higgins simply didn't earn the happy ending.Apart from that the film is too long. I think the biggest offenders are some of the less critical songs (i.e. opening day at Ascot) could have been termed. Further, Cukor's habit of stopping the action by freezing the characters for a few second to bookmark songs is really grating and makes the film feel stagey, while causing the pace to be off. I am really surprised the studio allowed that.On the whole this is a pleasant film to watch. Rex Harrison is really funny in his misanthropy. The film is slick polished lush filmmaking. If only the script didn't let the some of the misogyny pass.
Audrey Hepburn is really delicious, as do Rex Harrison. Frederick Loewe's music is beautiful, the movie is long. But, due to the charm of the two actors, it is being watched with pleasure.

(Flash Review)This WON EIGHT Oscars. I didn't realize it was a musical; 2hr 50min one at that. I'm not a big musical guy and watched this because I've always heard so much about it so now I can check it off. This must have been a stage play converted to film as the film sets felt very theatrical. The core story is high class gentleman agrees to a bet that he can take a gutter garbage woman (pretty close to the film's description) and turn her into someone who can blend into high class society. By teaching her how to speak properly and with an articulate vocabulary in addition to manners and attire. Mix in a love story amongst a variety of singing pieces that do advance the story and build out character depth. The dialog was clever, quick and snappy and some sets and costumes were elegant and grand. It did feel long, not overly engrossing and not in my movie wheelhouse.

reviews.review_title: Despite the ending, it's my favorite movie
reviews.content: I love this movie, and I can't entirely explain why. My husband took me to see the play, and I was almost in tears from happiness. It's partly nostalgia (I grew up with it), but partly that Eliza's story touches my soul.Audrey Hepburn is absolutely radiant in this film. She's my favorite actress, so I may be biased. IMO, she didn't have the strength to sing all of the songs (neither do I lol), so it makes sense that they dubbed her. Still, something about her performance makes the movie really, really resonate.Rex Harrison is really powerful as Higgins, even though I want to strangle him. Freddie is much more sympathetic than most iterations, and it works. Pickering is sweet in a clueless way, Alfred Dolittle is infuriating but hilarious, and Mrs. Higgins is perfection.The music is perfect. My favorite songs? Of course, On the Street Where You Live, I Could Have Danced All Night, and Without You. "You, dear friend, who talk so well/You can go to...Hartford, Hereford, and Hampshire!" So brilliant lol. And the ballroom scene? Also perfect.I hate the ending. Harrison's Higgins was not redeemable, and she should never have gone back to him (IMHO!). It took my family a long time (decades) to come up with this idea, and it's not universally appealing, but my mom and I think she shouldn't have stayed with Higgins or Freddie, but that Mrs. Higgins should have taken her in as a friend and daughter. They should have traveled the globe together, and when she passed, Mrs. Higgins should have left Eliza a comfortable sum to live on, as a thank you for filling the remainder of her life with so much joy. When someone uses that ending, then my faith in humanity will be restored (no need to give me the credit lol).But all griping aside, it is a truly incredible movie.

My Rating : 8/10Aubrey Hepburn is PERFECT in this film. Julie Andrews who was the original broadway star of 'My Fair Lady' simply didn't get the role because she was not a big star at the time. These things happen, film business is rather nasty business where box office success is paramount. Audrey Hepburn gives a great performance.'My Fair Lady' is a lively, entertaining and magical musical and an absolute joy to experience. It is undoubtedly a classic and a giant amongst Hollywood musicals.

Musicals.  You don't see them much at all anymore.  They're have been very few in the last few years but they are usually so enjoyable to watch. Chicago even won best picture.  Why do they not make these anymore I wonder? This film was awesome.  Hepburn is a great actress and her movies are wonderful.  To see her play two different types of people in this movie was very enjoyable.  Even though it was nearly 3 hours I was entertained the whole time.  Go out and see this movie and do it soon.  We need to bring more musicals back.

It seems hard to believe (among us aging Baby Boomers, that is)that the opulent film version of the famed Broadway musical "My Fair Lady" is nearing the 40th anniversary of its original release.When the movie premiered at NY City's Criterion Theatre in late October of 1964, the excitement anticipating its release was almost equal to the commotion that greeted the opening of "Gone With The Wind" in 1939. Producer Jack L. Warner spared no expense in transferring the Lerner and Loewe musical adaptation of Shaw's stage play "Pygmalion" to the screen. At the then astronomical cost of 17 million dollars, the Warner Brothers Studio artisans created the Edwardian world of Covent Garden, 27A Wimpole Street and environs into some of the most spectacular indoor sets ever created for the movies. Veteran cinematographer Harry Stradling captured all this in glorious Technicolor and Super Panavision 70, his camera lovingly recording for posterity Cecil Beaton's sets and costumes, lavish embellishments of the Broadway show. George Cukor, Hollywood's much revered "Woman's Director" guided his actors to thoroughly professional performances, with Rex Harrison dominating the film with his unforgettable portrayal of phonetics expert Henry Higgins, that irascible middle-aged bachelor who wagers a bet with an eminent colleague that in three months he can pass off a hapless flower girl into a duchess at an Embassy Ball. That flower girl, played in the movie by the lovely Audrey Hepburn, was a huge casting bone of contention among critics and public alike. Jack Warner hired Hepburn despite protestations that the original Broadway Eliza Doolittle, Julie Andrews, should repeat her memorable stage performance. But Andrews had never acted in movies, and Warner wanted to hedge his bets with a known name and quantity. In one of the great ironies of movie history, Julie Andrews took Hollywood by storm, starring in Walt Disney's own expensive musical extravaganza, "Mary Poppins", which beat "Fair Lady' to the screen a month earlier. It was "My Fair Lady", however, that triumphed at the April 5th, 1965 Oscar ceremony, winning 8 Academy Awards including the coveted Best Picture prize. In a delicious moment of sweet revenge, Julie Andrews picked up the Best Actress award for playing the titular Mary Poppins, the magical English nanny of her own Edwardian England. The other great irony in all this was that Audrey Hepburn failed to receive a Best Actress nomination for her very able work in "Fair Lady ". The question will always remain whether Andrews would have made "My Fair Lady " a better film.Perhaps so. But Hepburn is luminous, especially her transformation into a proper English Lady, where she really comes into her own. Her singing voice is dubbed by Marni Nixon, a prolific "ghost singer" for many actresses in film musicals who were not up to snuff in warbling demanding Broadway songs. Both "My Fair Lady" and "Mary Poppins" were the Crown Jewel entertainments of 1964, a time when the United States was still healing from the terrible emotional scars of the assassination of President Kennedy the year before. Some critics quibbled at the time that producer Warner embalmed "My Fair Lady" more than preserved it.Yes, it's stagy in the old fashioned Hollywood sense of the word. It's also a Grand Show that in its original 70 mm presentation was a visual knockout, something hard to duplicate in this age of Home Theatre Entertainment. The movie preserves for posterity one of the most brilliant musicals ever created, and with Rex Harrison's Henry Higgins, one of the greatest stage performances of all time.

This is a pretty good musical: the songs are snappy, the cinematography and choreography are great, and it has a pretty endearing story. The characters are what stand out most about it... Audrey Hepburn proves her worth and more alone, not to mention Rex Harrison and the support.It's sort of a loose remake of Pygmalion, which is in turn a play based off of the Greek myth... interestingly enough, having viewed this movie I now understand Pretty Woman to be a loose remake of My Fair Lady. In other words, this is a very recognizable story, though one focused a lot more on class consciousness of the Brits than most.The costuming is a little ridiculous, though from what I understand it's supposed to be--the absurd dresses the women wear are supposed to poke fun at the aristocracy. The horse race is probably one of the best parts in the movie, even if it's anything but subtle.I think really this film's strength lies almost entirely on Professor Higgins. He's such an easily detestable character, but still he's endearing and wonderful to watch. I think it's easy to disagree with him but it's wonderful to watch him as he struggles with his passions.--PolarisDiB

A very old film, suddenly watched on a whim. Audrey Hepburn's identity in "the kind and beautiful girl" is a flower seller at the bottom of society, vulgar in speech, fierce in behavior, clever in order to survive, and an alcoholic father. By chance, I met two linguists, and because of their bets, they were lucky to be the experimenters who had been transformed into ladies. Under the careful guidance of one of the linguists, Hepburn completed the process of turning sparrows into Phoenix, and at a grand party. Get in the limelight. The end of the film falls into the cliche of the general film, the linguist who holds the idea of celilism, unwittingly fell in love with Hepburn, and finally had a happy ending.
The film reveals that standard voice, gentleman and lady behavior and personal accomplishment are the standards of the middle class and upper class of that era, and people who do not have these conditions will be looked down upon. But for the sake of gentlemen and ladies in the eyes of all, the morality of the middle class became bound, losing the original free life and mind, as was the case with Hepburn's drinking father. Our lives now.Is there anything in common?
The story of linguists and flower sellers seems to be an example of love overcoming identity disparities, but if a flower seller does not become a lady and does not meet the basic conditions for a woman to enter the middle class, linguists will never fall in love with her overnight. After all, the story is that the story satisfies the fantasies of ordinary people. After reading it, life still has to go on.

I know a lot of people like MY FAIR LADY, and I like parts of it too-- but it comes up short on several important counts. Audrey Hepburn makes a valiant effort, but is trying TOO hard (probably to prove to her critics that she was not miscast). Unfortunately, despite how convincing she seems as a malnourished waif, she still seems wrong for the part.Meanwhile, Rex Harrison lacks the looks needed to be a romantic lead. He is no Leslie Howard-- and we certainly would not buy him as Romeo or Ashley Wilkes, so why should we buy him as Henry Higgins? If the producers had been able to get Cary Grant (whom director George Cukor wanted for the film version), I think it would have been better. And I don't mean Cary with Audrey, but Cary with Julie Andrews. Andrews would certainly have been able to pull off both the frumpy and more glamorous scenes. Plus, she would not need to have been dubbed.

George Cukor had a long distinguished career in Hollywood, culminating in achieving almost unanimous critical and huge commercial success with this extremely faithful adaption of the enormously successful Broadway musical; itself based on George Bernard Shaw's play Pygmalion. After winning 8 Academy Awards including best picture and director, many would support the contention, that this success was entirely justified and overdue, considering his earlier arguably unfair sacking from Gone With the Wind by producer David O Selznick, after contributing greatly to its production.Cukor had a reputation for eliciting fine performances from his leads and My Fair Lady is no exception. The almost 3 hour film is dominated by the characters of grumpy linguist Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) and socially aspiring street urchin come flower girl, Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn), who both excel in the ultimate romance realised after an extended comic, gender warfare scenario. Hepburn was widely criticised for being cast instead of Julie Andrews, a far superior singer famed for making the stage role of Eliza her own, though never accepted as film star material by producer Jack L Warner. No matter! Even though Andrews' angelic voice is missed by those familiar with the extremely popular Broadway recording, Hepburn's acting skills in interpreting the transformation of Eliza from whiney Cockney to a resplendent, independently-thinking woman cannot be faulted.The production and art design is outstanding in a film that features no exteriors. All the London locations are recreated impressively on Warner Bros sound stages. But crucially Cukor and his team which included cinematographer Harry Stradling Snr and Art Director/Costume Designer Cecil Beaton, avoid giving the impression, the production is just a filmed play. Instead they create the perfect environments to record memorable musical and mannered dancing sequences such as the Ascot Gavette and the Ambassador's Ball, where Lerner's and Lowe's songs are supremely realised in sumptuous settings, peopled with a cast invariably stylishly and alluringly and colourfully costumed.One point of criticism may be made around the film's pace. Much as Stanley Holloway's Alfie Doolittle is beloved, as are his two featured song and dance numbers, his extended songless interlude at Higgins's house in an attempt to extort money, has little really to do with the main storyline and means the charismatic Hepburn is offscreen for an appreciably noticeable time. One feels more refined editing may have limited this dead time and moved the story along more fluidly. It does beg the question of how faithful a film needs to be, of its stage musical roots?However the years have failed to dim the brightness of Cukor's achievement in creating a lasting Hollywood technicolor spectacle of irresistible music and song with a lightly satirical sub-text at English upper class expense. Without doubt, one of the great movie musicals!

I can't disagree with Pauline Kael when she says "My Fair Lady" "clunks" and "staggers" along. I can't disagree with people who complain that all the freshness has gone out of Rex Harrison's performance as Henry Higgins, as though he'd played the part a thousand times already. (1,006 times, according to the Warner Bros. souvenir book.)It's still wonderful to watch - a lovingly crafted big-budget movie that reminds you what made classic big-budget movies so enjoyable. How fortunate that Harrison's portrayal of Higgins, even if it's not at its peak, has been preserved on film. I'm perfectly willing to overlook the loverly Audrey Hepburn's shortcomings as Eliza Doolittle (I'd always known her Cockney was unconvincing; in later years, I came to realize her "fair lady" accent wasn't much better - she does not sound like an upper-class Englishwoman). Stanley Holloway is the delightful dustman, Alfred P. Doolittle, and Wilfrid Hyde-White plays Pickering. There's also the glorious Lerner & Loewe score, Harry Stradling's gorgeous Technicolor photography, Cecil Beaton's eye-filling costumes and scenery design, all under George Cukor's glossy direction.One qualm I have about the musical itself: Isn't it now a bit quaint to hear Professor Higgins declare that the salvation of the lower classes lies in successfully impersonating the manners and speech of the upper classes? Higgins may have thought he was promoting some kind of social equality, but wasn't he really tacitly endorsing the British class system with his attempts at surmounting it?

This film shows cinema at its finest in producing such a classy and acclaimed film and musical. Considering how cinema has taken a downward spiral with today's vulgar and thin plots this film could be considered as a remnant of the golden age of cinema. We see a refined and distrustful professor, Henry Higgins, who is cynical of everyone around him. From his maid, his close friends and even a simple unknown flower girl. As an accomplished and intelligent professor he is snobbish and part of high society. He is so confident in his abilities that he easily accepts a wager to change the flower girl he just made into a respectable lady. The acting from Rex Harrison deserves high praise, it is effortless and believable. The same can be said for Audrey Hepburn who plays the role of a low class person to perfection. We are also treated to first class music and performances from the cast, musicals never seemed so enjoyable. We see Henry teach Eliza how to be a lady and their constant quarrels. The experiment is such a success that high society is none the wiser as to her transformation. However Audrey feels like a prize or object in a rich white man's game. More importantly despite his success, the experience of tutoring Eliza has humbled him. The end of the film where they show respect and care for each other was a masterstroke as no romance was needed.

reviews.review_title: Great musical has a long history and a little controversy
reviews.content: "My Fair Lady" is one of the best musical films of all time. It certainly is one of the most extravagant productions ever put on film. And, it's a musical with a long history and a little controversy. More on that later.Audrey Hepburn stars as Eliza Doolittle. She is the "guttersnipe" flower girl from Covent Garden whom Higgins will teach to speak proper English and turn into a princess. Rex Harrison plays Henry Higgins – 'enry 'iggins, to Eliza. Both are superb in their roles. She's the poor, uneducated but brassy street girl who has a heart and who dreams. He's a highly educated, egotistical perfectionist – a dedicated bachelor who is very close to being a misogynist.Surrounding them are many gifted supporting players. Stanley Holloway reprises his stage role as Eliza's dad, Alfred P. Doolittle. He sings some wonderful, funny songs. Wilfrid Hyde-White is delightful as Col. Hugh Pickering. Gladys Cooper is Mrs. Higgins. She says she loses friends after her son's visits. Mona Washbourne is Mrs. Pearce, Henry's housekeeper. Theodore Bikel plays Zoltan Karpathy who was Higgins's first and star pupil. He knows 33 languages. And, Jeremy Brett plays Freddy Eynsford-Hill, who's smitten with Eliza.The story is an old one, updated to modern times in a play by George Bernard Shaw. Shaw actually won an Oscar (shared with three other writers) for the 1938 screenplay of his original play, "Pygmalion." The film by the same name received three more Oscar nominations in 1939, for best picture, best actor and best actress. Top British stars of the time, Leslie Howard and Wendy Hiller, had the lead roles.In 1954, Alan Jay Lerner succeeded in writing the play as a musical, with Frederick Loewe writing and composing the music. With its new title, "My Fair Lady" opened on Broadway on March 15, 1956 to rave reviews. When it closed on Sept. 29, 1962, it had set a record for Broadway musicals to that time with 2,717 performances.Warner Brothers paid a record $5.5 million for the movie rights. The studio got Harrison to reprise his role from Broadway, and Stanley Holloway to repeat as Alfred Doolittle. But – so the story goes, Jack Warner wasn't willing to take a chance on an untested screen actress for the part of Eliza Doolittle. Julie Andrews had created that part on stage, and she had a few TV performances behind her, including a 1957 musical special, "Cinderella." But Warner passed over her and went instead with Audrey Hepburn who was at the peak of her popularity and beloved by all. She had 10 years of film experience, and a number of big hits behind her – "Roman Holiday" of 1953, "Sabrina" of 1954, "War and Peace" of 1956, "Funny Face" of 1957, "The Nun's Story" of 1959, and "Charade" of 1963. The only hitch was that Hepburn was not a singer. She said so directly in film interviews. And that's wherein lies the controversy. Hepburn's songs were dubbed by Marni Nixon.Warner Brothers apparently wanted it kept secret, so the studio and performers talked around the subject in interviews. But the people in production all knew about it – especially the musicians and sound and editing staffs. And, Time magazine, even reported the dubbing way before the film's release. In a cynical article in its February 7, 1964 issue, the magazine said that the singing voice "on the sound track won't be Audrey's. It belongs to Marni Nixon, the ghostess with the mostest" At the Academy Awards the next spring, Julie Andrews won the best actress Oscar for "Mary Poppins." In her acceptance, she thanked Jack Warner for passing over her for the part in "My Fair Lady." Hepburn wasn't even nominated for "My Fair Lady," and some have speculated that Andrews may have won with a sentiment vote. In a 1995 documentary on the making of "My Fair Lady," Julie Andrews said she will never know. While she'd like to think it was for her performance in "Mary Poppins," she thought it might have been based on sentiment.Ever the lady and kind performer herself, Andrews's guess may be partly right. Composer and musician Harold Lloyd Weber in that same documentary, said that in England people were surprised that Hepburn got the role because Andrews had so nailed the role in the stage play when it played there. And, if audiences can be a sign of how the members of the Academy might vote, then the signs looked bright for Andrews and Mary Poppins.While "Lady" won eight Oscars with four more nominations, "Poppins" won five Oscars with 8 more nominations. And "Poppins" out-earned "Lady" by a huge amount. "Lady" grossed $72 million on a budget of $17 million. But "Poppins" grossed more than $102 million in the U.S. on a budget of $6 million."My Fair Lady" was restored in 1995 and preserved from near loss. A 1995 documentary, "Making of My Fair Lady," gives much interesting background on the film. It comes with the DVD in some packages. I give some of the fascinating facts in my comments on that film.I have a CD recording of the stage performance of "My Fair Lady." Julie Andrews puts tremendous life into the songs. While I enjoy Audrey Hepburn in this film, I would have loved to hear Julie Andrews singing Eliza's role on film."Controversy aside, this is a fine film that many people should enjoy for a long time to come. Audrey Hepburn and Julie Andrews are both superb performers and fine people. Future generations will be able to enjoy much of the great work they have left us.

reviews.review_title: Audrey Hepburn Walks on the street Julie Andrews where Lived
reviews.content: In this musical version of George Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion" (1912), middle-aged bachelor Rex Harrison (as Henry Higgins) thinks he can turn "guttersnipe" teenager Audrey Hepburn (as Eliza Doolittle) into an elegant lady. The professor works on the cockney girl's poise and linguistics. Displaying his protégée at a grand ball, Mr. Harrison fools everyone into thinking "Eliza" must be royalty. Harrison congratulates himself. Feeling used, Ms. Hepburn throws a tantrum. Drifting from the original characters, she and Harrison have fallen in love... This is an immaculately produced version of the stage hit, but the magnificent collection of songs contributed by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe remain what make "My Fair Lady" good. Note how young versus mature love is expressed in progression from "On the Street Where You Live" to (celebrating Harrison's love for a girl) "I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face". Other song highlights include "Wouldn't it Be Loverly?" and "I Could Have Danced All Night", both of which you will likely recall as being performed by Julie Andrews... This is because Ms. Andrews' versions remain the standards. The "Original Cast" LP album featuring Andrews and Harrison (they originally co-starred in the stage hit) was a #1 multi-platinum hit, with Andrews' vocals receiving most of the radio airplay. A decade later, the Andrews LP still easily outsold the "Original Soundtrack" LP accompanying this film. This only serves to illustrate the fact that Hepburn was painfully miscast in the Andrews role. And, it wasn't only the dubbing; Hepburn was always a lady, from the opening scenes.****** My Fair Lady (10/21/64) George Cukor ~ Audrey Hepburn, Rex Harrison, Stanley Holloway, Wilfrid Hyde-White

reviews.review_title: Better you see the stage show
reviews.content: A musical juggernaut that trundles on forever. Shaw's play was splendid and not because of its irksomely misogynist story-line but because Shaw created characters that were believable in themselves and not because of their situations and he gave them splendid pithy lines to say. In turning it into a musical the writer Alan Jay Lerner had the sense to retain the best of Shaw while Frederick Loewe's music was innocuous enough to prove too much of a distraction. Indeed, the songs in "My Fair Lady" fit the action more comfortably than is usual and the original stage show marked a departure for the stage musical by incorporating the songs seamlessly into the narrative. It has always proved an energizing evening in the theatre.George Cukor's film version works on the axiom that if it isn't broke there is no need to fix it. Cukor was never a 'filmic' director. He was fine director of actors and he loved the written word. Perhaps the most innovative thing about "My Fair Lady" was its refusal to be anything but filmed theatre on a very massive scale. There is no attempt to open it out from its stage-bound origins. You feel as if you are in the best seats in the stalls of the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane.Nor was he an innovative director of musicals. Plonking his camera in front of the performers was his idea of how to record a number but since, in this instance, the songs and the narrative were very much one and the same, this hardly mattered. And it preserves Rex Harrison's great performance as Higgins. Harrison had played the role so often on the stage like breathing out and breathing in it was second nature to him.His Eliza was more problematic. Fearing that Broadway's Julie Andrews was an unknown quantity producer Jack Warner cast, instead, Audrey Hepburn, an established star, then had her songs dubbed by Marni Nixon. Andrews' revenge was an Oscar for "Mary Poppins" while Hepburn failed to get a nomination. The film version also preserves Stanley Holloway's indelible Doolittle while Cecil Beaton's sets and costumes are even more stunning on the (very) big screen than they were in the theatre. So it certainly looks the part and for a great deal of the time it sounds it, too. It's 'an entertainment', overlong at three hours and not to everyone's temperament, set more in aspic than in stone. Best you see it on the stage.

reviews.review_title: Opulent, Charming and Captivating; A Very-Intelligent Late Musical
reviews.content: This film is famous for the preceding history it boasted as a fine play and successful film "Pygmalion" written by perverse major-talent playwright George Bernard Shaw; for the opulent production accorded its production by MGM's executives; and for the controversy surrounding the handing of its female lead to Audrey Hepburn and not to its its Broadway leading lady Julie Andrews; for the strange choices made in awarding other roles to less-than-ideal choices; and for the lovely musical additions by Alan Jay Lerner and Frederic Loewe that are perhaps more celebrated by now than even the musical film itself--numbers such as ""Why Can't the English Teach Their Children How to Speak", "With a Little Bit o' Luck", "Wouldn't It Be Loverly", "The Rain in Spain", "Let a Woman in Your Life", "On the Street Where You Love", "I Could Have Danced All Night", "Get Me to the Church On Time" and The Ascot Gavotte", Show Me" and "I've Grown Accustomed To Face", among others. The story-line of the original play is retained; and it is relatively simple. Professor of phonetics Henry Higgins encounters a colleague from India, Colonel Pickering who has come to see him, on a street outside a major theater. He criticizes a flower-girl's speech, remarking offhandedly that in six months he could her off as a lady--or a shop girl, which requires better English; that it is her accent which keeps her in lower-class poverty. The girl comes the next day, to his home where Higgins is entertaining his new guest, and offers to pay for training. Higgins is a social monster and frightens the girl with his rough talk, but he agrees to take her on, and sends her to his housekeeper to be given a bath and have her clothes burned and replaced--which act turns out to precipitate a major battle... At one point, her ne'er-do-well father, Alfred P. Doolittle, demands money to overlook the Professor's theft of his daughter, Eliza, meaning the income she had provided him; he uses the money to get married. The training proves difficult and arduous; Higgins' mother is amused and frightened by the experiment, set off by Pickering's wagering Higgins could not train the girl. But he does; Eliza proves to be bright, touchy, emotional and altogether more interesting than Higgins had expected. She succeeds, masters an upper-class accent; and then in rapid succession, she is presented at a party to social highbrows where her accent is perfect but the content of her speech is Cockney matters, which they take for a fashionable new court slang, and then she upsets the Ascot Race Meeting crying to the horse she has bet on, "Move yer bloomin' arse!", but charms Freddie Eynesford-Hill who becomes her shy suitor. At last the Professor presents her at a a royal ball where she charms everyone concerned, avoids any major faux pas, and convinces a bogus Hungarian phoneticist she must be royal herself. So the experiment has succeeded; Higgins has won his bet. Then he discovers, as a distraught Eliza confronts him the next day, that he has done what he had set out to do--he has created a person capable of self-assertion in the world, but not in the flawed British Empire's stratified and totalitarian society. She leaves him, to marry Freddy; and he discovers he has fallen in love with her. She recognizes that Freddy is unworthy of her and, despite the lack of promises and guarantees from Higgins, returns to do battle with him--for the rest of their lives, perhaps. The entire production looks unarguably lovely, even the Covent Garden faked scene, and a very difficult mixture of faked outdoor and elaborate indoor settings it must have been. Director George Cukor, famed for his skill with actors, gets a near-perfect job of acting from Rex Harrison as Higgins and quite a bit from Audrey Hepburn as Eliza. Others prominent in the large but briefly-seen cast include Theodore Bikel as the Hungarian hairy hound from Budapest, Mona Washbourne as the housekeeper, Isobel Elsom as Mrs Eynesford-Hill, Jeremy Brett as Freddy, Wilfrid Hyde-White as an acceptable Pickering, Stanley Holloway as Papa Dolittle, and Gladys Cooper adequate as Higgins' mother. The screenplay was by Alan Jay Lerner, and the cinematography by Harry Stradling, Sr. The production design and the lovely, colorful art direction must be credited to Cecil Beaton and to Gene Allen in both cases; Beaton also did the fabulously-expensive costumes with Michael Neuwirth. Despite its opulence, the film has consistent style, a very good flow of events and scarcely any look about it of sound-stage claustrophobia, re-hashed stage setting or extraneously-introduced musical numbers. This is a fine late musical achievement from the studio talents that produced of Hollywood's best US musicals, and the most beautiful to watch. It could have been cold and curiously overly-polished; instead it turned out to be a rather genial classic that is genuinely fun to watch in my view, and surprisingly more interesting than one had any right to expect it could be as an on-screen extravaganza.

reviews.review_title: A Nice Film but Not the Greatest as Many Say
reviews.content:
I've had an interesting relationship with this movie over the young years of my life and I still have mixed feelings about it. My Fair Lady is often cited as one of the greatest films of all time, or at the very least "the only perfect musical." Its impact on film culture is indeed undeniable but I agree with the late Robert Osbourne of Turner Classic Movies. He stated that it is a nice movie but it is not essential and it has many problems its contemporaries could have overcome better than this. But I will try to be Fair to the film.The story involves street urchin Eliza (Audrey Hepburn) who's cockney is so thick her peers even comment on it. By happenstance, she encounters an arrogant phonetic expert, Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) who believes a person's manner of speech is what separates urchin from duchess. They strike a bargain that he can teach her to speak like a princess and pass her off as one to prove his theory, whereas she could possibly gain proper employment at a flower shop. Their relationship is fraught as both are headstrong and stubborn, but eventually she "gets it" and speaks properly. But the question arises: Will Higgin's views and strict teachings help or hinder her?I'll start off with the elements of the film that work very well for me. Rex Harrison nails a mysonginistic character with a heart, he doesn't seem all that aware that what he's saying is hurtful as his passion for what he does blinds him to the heart of the woman he's trying to mold. The supporting cast is decently assembled, with the standout supporting player being Stanley Holloway as Eliza's ne'er do-well alcoholic father Alfie, who gives the movie life it desperately needs at times. I am of the opinion that almost any score from the great duo of Lerner and Lowe is going to be absolutely wonderful and this movie is no exception. There are smatterings of brilliance in the dialogue and the story development but unfortunately this leads into many of the movie's problems.Chief among the films problems is it is far too overblown. The same issue arises in films like Seven Brides for Seven Brothers and Hello Dolly, the issue of large sets and huge casts of hundreds in costume but have zero zest to them and come off as way to stylized to make an emotional connection. There is a difference between portraying aristocrats with a slight tongue in cheek attitude and then theres this movie where I laughed with incredulity at how people could possibly think this is a great movie. I like George Cukor as a director but here, he tends to keep his cast and sets in medium shots and even wide shots, which does nothing to help the story. And when there are close-ups they are uncomfortable when they are meant to be endearing and vice-versa.I need to address the elephant in the room and discuss Audrey Hepburn's performance and how it ties the the story. I love Audrey Hepburn and when she speaks the part, she is interesting and almost compelling. I do not mind that she was dubbed but Jack Warner made a horrific decision to do so for two reasons: 1) It sounds like most of the cast was not dubbed by someone else (save for Jeremy Brett which itself is odd) thus her dubbing sticks out like a sore thumb
2) Yes Julie Andrews was passed over and once people saw her in Mary Poppins it didn't seem right when the talent was there and an executive didn't even give her a chance to screen test for it
However, this is not my issue with the story or Hepburn's performance, but rather Alan Jay Lerner's screenplay. The dialogue sparkles and the characters established, but the narrative is hopelessly weak as opposed to its source material, Shaw's Pygmalion. Eliza starts as a stubborn urchin who yearns for a life better than rescuing her flowers from puddles. However, she is constantly seen as less than by Higgins, and she decides to strike out on her own. Good for you! But then she decides to complain to his mom and rub it in his face like a woman scorned, which doesn't strike me as a logical progression for her character. And the ending cripples a possibly progressive and powerful message that Shaw achieved wonderfully.So my final thoughts are this. I'm glad this movie means so much for people and it nearly clicked with me, but too many things just prevented me from embracing it. I do not think it was the best film of 1964 by any stretch. I think Mary Poppins, Dr. Strangelove, and even Becket were better films which took risks and delivered something better than this film. I'm glad I've seen it and I even hum some of the songs once and a while, but My Fair Lady isn't a perfect flower for me.

This review contains spoilers.My Fair Lady is a musical film directed by George Cukor and stars Rex Harrison and Audrey Hepburn. The film is about a poor Cockney flower seller and a phonetics professor that seeks to improve the flower seller's accent and place in society. The movie follows these two characters throughout its 170 minute running time. Professor Henry Higgins, played by Rex Harrison, frequently coaches Eliza Doolittle, played by Audrey Hepburn.My Fair Lady is an incredibly lengthy movie at 170 minutes of running time. I did not feel the length as the movie was frequently entertaining with its musicals. The musicals and songs help drive the narrative with each song helping the audience understand where the two characters are at. The actual plot of this movie can be squashed into a 90 minute film. Thankfully this is not the case as the length of the movie actually aids in the enjoyment of it. This movie has many other good components besides the long musicals.Audrey Hepburn does a great job with her role of Eliza Doolittle. She starts off as a low-class woman that dreams of working a flower shop. She undergoes a transformation by the end of the movie by actually evolving into the character Henry Higgins wanted. This transformation was not total as Eliza still had her own ambitions. She has a great arc through the entire running time. Audrey Hepburn also does a good job portraying the character through the highs and lows.Rex Harrison as Professor Henry Higgins does a great job as the misanthropic professor. He too undergoes a character arc and by the end of the movie comes to an appreciation for Eliza Doolittle. The character and his mannerisms are well acted by Rex Harrison. I enjoyed this character even when it seemed he was being too cruel to Eliza Doolittle. Many of the scenes involving the two main leads are great to watch and enjoy.The supporting cast of this movie does a good job. I do not think there are any weaknesses in the casting choices. All of the characters do a good job in the musical scenes they are in or offer a nice moment with the main characters.The movie can drag for audiences that are not into musicals. This movie can feel excruciatingly slow if the audience does not like musicals. To audiences that are not interested in the musical aspects, they should still give this movie a chance.I highly recommend My Fair Lady.Grade: A

The now famous musical adaptation of Pygmalion with Rex Harrison as the arrogant elocution teacher Professor Henry Higgins who bets that he can turn Cockney flower seller Audrey Hepburn into a real lady and falls in love in the process. It is truly amazing to me the kind of unbridled affection that viewers and film historians have for this adaptation of the stage musical considering how devoid of passion the final result on screen is. Director George Cukor has crafted a technically lovely looking film, but the magic is muted and the enchantment of the stage hit is sorely wanting. Harrison was tapped to recreate his stage success, but filmmakers passed over Julie Andrews to gift the role of Eliza Dolittle to non-singer Audrey Hepburn (she is dubbed by Marni Nixon). Hepburn is truly lovely here, but she is no where near the immortal asset to the film that fans like to pretend. What is amazing about My Fair Lady - the screen version - is how much it makes one think fondly of OTHER screen musicals. Life is desperately needed here and on vastly short order. For instance, Stanley Holloway's purportedly show-stopping numbers as rendered on screen have a surprisingly MEH factor. When Eliza sings effervescently that she could have "danced all night" with Higgins, what she refers to on screen is a couple of clunky turns around Higgins' cramped study. Many of the numbers are deservedly familiar, but one walks away thinking they could have been staged much better than presented - particularly against the absurdly phony backgrounds. Harrison's stuffed shirt Higgins wears thin quickly. He is arrogant, preening and obnoxious, and it is virtually impossible to root for a romantic coupling between he and Eliza. The film's strong misogynistic streak may come from the source, but the screenplay here does nothing to soften it. Eliza raises a good point when she draws Higgins' attention to the fact that now that he has raised her consciousness and turned her into a lady - what can she do now? The fact that he considers her an ingrate and gets insulted says all we need to know about a pompous, vainglorious character that fails to evolve. It says a lot when the viewer actually hopes Eliza will take up teaching and marry young aristocrat Freddy, who actually adores her for herself, rather than settle for a life of servitude with Higgins. The film's final scene with Eliza puzzlingly returning to Higgins and him barking at her to get his slippers is decidedly disheartening. A classic that is nice to see once, but whose reputation has become too bloated to be believed.

reviews.review_title: "Why can't a woman be more like a man?"
reviews.content: Maybe it wasn't the right mood I was in, or maybe not seeing it in its intended MASSIVE theatrical presentation on 70mm *Super* Panavision (the kind that The Hateful Eight was shot in, to give an idea of the rarity of its stock), or maybe I wasn't in the mood for a shrill musical where the songs weren't to my liking, but this is one of those classics I just didn't get. I don't want to take this away from you if you love it or think you'd be in for this experience that is Alan Jay Lerner adapting George Bernard Shaw with Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison in two of their most identified roles (this isn't to say best or not best, just that when you think of them this has to pop up). And there are a couple of good things I can say about it, which I'll get to later on here.But I wasn't having the first hour of this at the least, where Hepburn is Eliza Doolittle (no relation to the doctor later played by Harrison, unless that was some intentional coincidence I didn't get), and she is a flower girl (basically a girl of the street, except not a prostitute), and Hepburn plays it with an obnoxious accent. It could all be in the writing from Lerner and the collaborators, but I think Hepburn can be taken to task too. I think I read she thought she was miscast, and she was probably correct - this needed a stronger, younger woman in the role who could play younger AND older with conviction, and Hepburn can do the latter but not the former so much. When she sings she's fine, but with the exception of the flagship song, "I Could've Danced All Night," the songs are prattling, talking too much in song, just... ugh.Rex Harrison is fun as Higgins - maybe he could've played this in his sleep, but he still is trying, and that's appreciated - but Higgins is also a character who is a fairly outspoken misogynist, and this dates the movie. I get how it seemed probably at the time, and I had a couple of chuckles at his blustering, but by near the end of the story he hasn't really changed that much as a character. Even if he sees Eliza differently, as not the flower girl but as a real "woman" who's main attribute is fighting back and standing her ground, will he see other women the same now? Is this change only about his attraction and desire for her (whether it's chaste or not), or is it all shallow, like a lot of this movie may seem to be? I know the song about 'Why can't a woman be more like a man" is meant to show how out of it he is, but it's not enough, at least for me (even if, again, Harrison tries to sell it his 'upper-crust' British best, seriously, he's the best thing about the movie).Sure, the movie is pretty - Cukor and Warner didn't spare much expense with this (okay, maybe a little, but it's not a story that requires the fx of Mary Poppins or Sound of Music's epic scope - and that is something else I can give it, up to a point. But I think that concretely I just couldn't get into it as a musical. I didn't enjoy the song as much as I should've or thought I would, and while a couple are fairly catchy (the song the men sing in the street, "With a Bit of Luck", is tolerable), for many of the songs I felt myself biding my time until they were over. Comparatively to Poppins again, as both were from 1964, this doesn't fare or age as well as a musical either.Again, if you like the songs then more than likely you'll dig the movie. If this review is for anyone it's people on the fence unsure whether a movie musical that was based on an earlier play (which I remember reading in school but vaguely and then got remade as She's All That, which... okay, My Fair Lady at least makes more *sense* than that does when it comes to transforming its female creature for a bet). Despite how a few scenes do have their moments - when Eliza does sort of 'break' from character that she's just cracked with some elite people at a horse race, that's amusing - it's bloated at 3 hours, and in its way kind of portends the more rancid musicals to come in the late 60's.And, lastly, as a story of class distinctions, it's... okay. You know how it's going to end up, mostly, especially as this is deeper down a romantic comedy as much as a musical. But, except for one emotional scene between Eliza and Higgings after that big regal reception (and after a musical number where, wisely cinematography-wise, she's in the background of the room) that does hit its mark well as far as how far apart these people are, I just... well, I just didn't care so much. If it does, then fine! If not, I feel for you!

"My Fair Lady" never fails to hit the spot. It looks great. The songs are (mostly) also great. The cast is top-notch. The jokes are funny. "My Fair Lady" is a long movie but it's also a wildly satisfying experience. This movie never gets old. It's a true classic.

reviews.review_title: I don't care if my friend make fun of me but I love this movie
reviews.content: This is one of the best if not the best musical out there. Rex Harrison did was perfect and Audrey Hepburn could not have been funnier. There are very few times when I actually stop by to admire the costumes, but the costumes are one of my favorite parts of the movie and in a way really move the story forward and gives us endless character development. The race track scene is one of my favorite scenes of all time and everything about it is perfect. The costumes of course (I love how Rex Harrison's suit stands out in an almost garish way), and the lighting and choreography of the scene. There are very few times when I actually think that the placements of the extras was perfect, but it was in this scene. I could talk about this scene all day, but I will move on. The songs are surprisingly catchy and not over the top (like Hello Dolly). I liked how the dance numbers involved people that could not really dance and really looked like people off the street. The last thing I want to point out is one of standout moments of the movie is when the street is just getting going in the morning and the extras freeze in waves and then start moving. I love that scene and regard it as one of the more original scenes in any movie I have seen. The end was also nice because unlike more "romantic comedies" did not have the big mushy moment at the end but ended with grace with a very personal moment shared by two people that loved each other.

reviews.review_title: As a female its a bit of a bruh moment
reviews.content: I like Audrey and usually i try not to think too much into it with old films but this wasn't that much fun if you relate to Eliza . The status and power dynamic of Higgins relationship to Eliza was made pretty apparent within the fist 15 minutes of the film when he thew her coins saying "a reminder" in a cold voice and dismissed her. Higgins at one point proceeds to sing a semi-homoerotic song about how he wished women were more like men that I found quite funny to watch as a he sounds a bit like a reddit incel on a rant.

First of all, I love Audrey Hepburn, symbol of elegance. This musical is so pure.story is a little long and super cliché for our year but in '64, probably it was unique. Actually I don't like all songs, rain in Spain is my favorite in the movie. Last I wanna tell about wardrobe, it is just perfect, fenomenale, beyond time, not only Eliza's clothes, every single piece is incredible, hats, hair accessories, men's toxidos.... I love this classic movie and I feel so lucky for watching this masterpiece.

reviews.review_title: The greatest music ever, overall, but saddled with a problematic screenplay.
reviews.content: Amazingly, perhaps the two best musicals ever with no or minimal stage dancing were released in successive years, in 1964 and '65., each winning the Oscar for best picture. Both screenplays were essentially yet another take on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, the lead female starting out as a 'nobody', taken under the wing of a domineering bachelor, who either makes a conscious effort to mold her into his ideal woman(this film) or allows himself to fall in love with what she makes of herself("The Sound of Music"). Judging by their comparative mean IMDB ratings, and by the much greater number of reviews for the latter, I have to conclude that the latter film is the more popular. I'm not surprised, as it clearly is a more fun film, including a bevy of children, lacking the present film. Also, Captain von Trapp clearly is a much nicer man than the megalomaniacal Henry Higgins, who seems to fall in love with his creation: a beautified and sophisticated, on the surface, Elisa, but doesn't consumate his attraction to her at film's end("Bring me my slippers"). Captain von Trapp is a changed man, for the better, thanks to the personality of Maria. In contrast, Henry Higgins is still the egotistical misanthrope at the end, gloating over his 'impossible' transformation of 'Elisa'.On the other hand, I would judge the body of songs of the present film to be the equal of that of "The Sound of Music". At nearly 3 hr. Long, both films were were a challenge to sit through comfortably in theater chairs. Thank goodness, now, with recordings we can purchase, we can break them up into partial viewings, and hopefully in a more comfortable situation than theater chairs!..........Some can overlook Higgin's personality and treatment of Eliza, and rate the film a 9 or 10. I can only partially do so.

I don't think there is an element of My Fair Lady that anyone cannot love or admire. Perhaps you like the catchy, joyful tunes. Or maybe you enjoy the gorgeous vintage fashions. Or instead the Cinderella-style story line? Are you an Audrey/Rex fan? Do you like funny lines? Or are you really into classic movies/musicals? There are so many more reasons why you should see this movie. With so many wonderful musical compositions it is undoubtedly one of the most successful, enjoyable and watchable musicals of all time. It is not corny, it is realistic - unlike some other musicals. Audrey Hepburn is wonderful in this - most of the cast is, really. So you don't have to worry about crappy acting and actually feeling sorry for the actors making complete fools of themselves! You don't have to worry about listening to a boring tune. It is such a lovely musical to watch, I recommend it to everyone. And if you don't like musicals, why don't you take a look at this one? It could change you mind. It is a wonderful movie that you can watch over and over again.

reviews.review_title: Shaw is spinning in his grave...
reviews.content: This lame musical, so grossly overrated, can't hold a candle either to other musicals of the same time (The Music Man) or to the stage play upon which it is based. The musical is woefully miscast at every turn, and I can only say that anyone who thinks well of it has missed the 30s film version and Shaw's wonderful skill.1) Hepburn is a lovely girl, and a good actress. She's a bad choice for the Eliza role because she's TOO lovely. No one in their right mind would believe her as a common guttersnipe. Compare to the 30s Eliza, Wendy Hiller -- who is just plain enough to play her, yet scrubs up excellently.2) Harrison is a lame choice for Higgins, and totally misses the role. Harrison plays him as a cold fish, right to the core, whereas the 30s Higgins, Leslie Howard, nailed it right on -- Higgins is a very passionate man who has subordinated his passion into his language studies. Eliza becomes the subject of his passion -- first as his student, then as a woman (hence Shaw's title, Pygmalion, with Eliza his Galatea).3) All the smaller roles, from Pickering and "The Count", to Freddie and Eliza's father, are all far better cast in the 30s film.4) The idea that a play, written by a master of the stage like Shaw, can be converted to a musical is as ridiculous as colorizing a Hitchcock film (and yes, it's true people are stupid enough to have done both). Shaw is arguably the second greatest playwright of the English language (and certainly *one* of the best), and his use of dialogue is as masterful and mindful of its rhythms as Hitchcock's use of light and shadow. The songs in MFL only serve to disrupt those rhythms. The 30s film, mind you, had the screenplay adapted by Shaw himself, so I believe it is safe to presume that the play's rhythms were retained in the film.All in all, if you watch the 30s film before you see MFL, you'll be greatly annoyed with the excess of acclaim given the latter. It's lame at best, and overrated by any measure. I say: *Hack-ptui*.

Professor Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) is a pompous brilliant linguist who boasts that he could turn cockney flower girl Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn) into a lady in 6 months. She's hounded by her drunken father (Stanley Holloway) for money. She wants to have lessons from Higgins and Colonel Pickering (Wilfrid Hyde-White) makes a bet with him.This is a fun musical. As with some musicals of that era, Hepburn's singing is dubbed. No one would dare do that today, but one must not dismiss this movie for doing it back in the day. Hepburn plays the role older. It would help to play up her age. Her older age only helps to create chemistry between her and Harrison. Hepburn is as always very adorable. She is a brilliant comic actress. She and Rex Harrison are great foils for each other. This is a good funny acting duo.

reviews.review_title: The creepiest musical film in the history
reviews.content: Every aspect of this film is obnoxious and disgusting. This is gaslighting story in which a grumpy, cranky old man keeps inculcating that Eliza's appearance is not noble, that her accent is low-class.Eliza Doolittle is portrayed repugnant as well. To make the story right, the only thing that changes after makeover is outside such as garment, accent, manner, and etc. Eliza's inside is the same, but people tend to judge based on outside. However, after Mr. Higgins' lessons, she becomes a totally different person. Audrey Hepburn's portrayal of Eliza is misleading and an eye-sore. Audrey Hepburn is only fit to have graceful and luxurious roles as you can see in the later of this movie.Music in musical film is so important, but 'My Fair Lady' fails to have any memorable and strong scores. Also, audience can obviously tell Audrey Hepburn does not sing, but it's dubbed. Choreography is non-existent and awkward if it has any. People stop during the choreography, making it so unnatural. Finally, this film is stretched without any obvious reason, this lengthy storytelling drags people out. Phonetic lesson scene is extremely long-winded that I could correct my pronunciation, too. Eliza's father's wedding scene is out of nowhere.

This is one of my favourite sixties movies. Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison were great in this movie. I have to say it was kind of weird seeing Audrey talking cockney. My favourite songs were, 'Wouldn't It Be Loverly', 'I Could've Danced All Night', 'The Street Where You Live'. I think it was a shame Audrey's singing voice was dubbed by Marni Nixon. Audrey looked beautiful in the film. I'm glad Julie Andrews was not cast as Eliza Doolittle (not that I dislike Julie)she couldn't play Eliza all the time. I hate how Audrey was treated because she played Eliza instead of Julie Andrews and I also hate how Audrey never got nominated for an Oscar.

reviews.review_title: Very well done because Shaw's searing social commentaries made it into the dialog and amazingly, even into the music.
reviews.content: Loewe's name should have been up there in the IMDb credits beside that of Lerner. The tunes of this musical movie are simply unforgettable. And, assisted by the lyrics of Lerner which hewed closely (sometimes even exactly) to the social commentaries of Shaw, the songs are gems.As a young man, my favorite was On the Street Where You Live but I couldn't help being attracted to With a Little Bit of Luck because Stanley Holloway and his crew were simply a riot with their words and antics in this campy and scampy number.Holloway stole the thunder from everyone (even from the venerable Rex Harrison) each time he appeared on a scene. That repartee between him and Harrison (Prof. Higgins) where he chided the latter about his "middle class morality" is pure Bernard Shaw social commentary. I simply love his cockney accent and I don't think that rib-tickling song I'm Getting Married in the Morning could be sung without it. I believe he got an Oscar (supporting actor) for his role in this film.

reviews.review_title: The most intelligent musical ever made
reviews.content: My Fair Lady is, as my summary states, the most intelligent musical ever made. Adapted by Lerner and Lowe from non-musical Pygmalion by George Bernard Shaw, it is filled with clever, witty dialogue. Lavish sets, a superb cast, and wonderful songs make this film a masterpiece. Even sceptics of musicals (those who say they can't stand them because nobody bursts into song) will enjoy it.You can get the plot from the myriad of other reviews, so let me comment on what makes this musical such a treat for the mind, as well as the eye and ear.The intelligence comes from the satire of the British class society, the hilarious comments on morality from Doolittle, and the comments about the roles of the sexes in the "songs" of Henry Higgins. People (men, especially) will roar at his comments about women. Sure, they're stereotypes, incorrect generalizations. But do men think that way? Well, what do you think of his claim that: "She will beg you for advice, your reply will be concise, she will listen very nicely and go out and do precisely what she wants!"Rex Harrison's Higgins is such an interesting character. Certainly he's insulting and insensitive. But what makes him fascinating is that he knows he is like that. "The moment I make friends with a woman I become selfish and tyrannical," he says. Does he treat Eliza poorly? Certainly, but no more poorly than he treats anybody else, which is, therefore, giving her equality with everyone else despite her lower class origins.A wonderful, poignant scene occurs as Eliza returns, as a lady, to the streets before dawn, where the working class is setting up for the days market. In her earlier life, she would have been there, buying the flowers to sell to the upper classes. Now, as the people hum and whistle a song we heard her sing at the movie's start, she finds she can no longer fit in. "This is no place for a lady, ma'am," a bloke says to her gently. So what has her "education" got her?The stage version of My Fair Lady held the record for most performances for a decade. The LP became the highest selling LP ever, of all genres, not just cast recordings.Please watch My Fair Lady, especially the restored DVD version. It's a true classic. You will see the character that Rex Harrison was born to play, and the character that Audrey Hepburn became. (Upon her death, Time Magazine remembered her with the photograph of her from My Fair Lady.) (Note: No review is complete without pointing out that true musical fans know that Julie Andrews, who played the role on Broadway, SHOULD have had the film version. Jack Warner wanted a bigger name. So Andrews became Mary Poppins, and accepted an Oscar for best actress with a thank you to Jack Warner for making it possible!)

Based on the play by Shaw, this really is a gem of film-making from the 1960s musical era. It's hard to go wrong with Rex Harrison and above all the divine Audrey Hepburn.In this ignorance-to-education story, a diamond in the rough is taken from gutter snipe to lady, mainly by teaching language. The conceit is that you are what you talk like.The tension arises because dear Mr. 'Enry 'Iggins, a self-declared language expert and Eliza's teacher and foil, is really a pretty nasty character: sexist, rough-mannered, although he thinks of himself as the epitome of humanity. His best excuse is that "he does it to everyone equally." Not quite true, he treats his male friend Hyde-White certainly better than his housekeeper or poor Eliza.The film features awesome songs (maybe one out of a dozen or so is meh, the rest are among the best Broadway has ever seen), amazing costumes, and a caterpillar-to-butterfly transformation of Audrey Hepburn's character that leaves the viewer spellbound the whole time. The side characters, like the puffed-up Hungarian count who seeks to demask Eliza, Higgins' mother, who knows what an ornery fellow her son is, Eliza's dad, an intelligent but downtrodden free spirit, are all nicely drawn.Modern audiences will find Higgins a bit grating - he remains unrepentant and a sexist pig to the last - but hey, times were not as politically correct in the early 20th century, when Britain was still lording it over India and suffragettes were marching through the streets demanding the women's vote. The movie is an interesting stylized vignette of turn-of-the-century British society both low and high, as conceived by George Bernard Shaw and viewed through the lens of the 60s, and the cinematography, music, acting, singing and the hats, oh the hats, are all amazing.

reviews.review_title: Turning a tramp into more than a lady
reviews.content:
The old Greek myth is about Pygmalion the artist who makes a statue come alive as a beautiful lady. Bernard Shaw turned the story the other way, making a fresh natural original young woman turn into a statue by brainwashing her into speaking well. The musical is not quite according to Bernard Shaw's intentions, and in the impersonation by Audrey Hepburn the statue/street girl turns into what neither Bernard Shaw nor Henry Higgins intended or expected. The difference is made by the lyrics, the music and Audrey Hepburn.
Many expected her to get an Oscar for her part, but it went instead to Julie Andrews for Mary Poppins. Julie Andrews had played Eliza Dolittle innumerable times on stage with Rex Harrison as Higgins and with tremendous success, making the musical one of the most successful of all times, and it was almost expected that she would also be given the part on film. Instead, the movie part went to Audrey Hepburn, and naturally the question rises, whether Julie Andrews with her professional musical routine would have made it better, especially in view of the Oscar she received for Mary Poppins. It's possible, that she would have made it better, but she would hardly have made it more beautiful. Audrey Hepburn as Eliza actually emerges as a lady in spite of Higgins' rude bullying, and played by Audrey Hepburn she actually becomes quite convincing as a princess if not a queen - she becomes more than a lady, more beautiful, more noble and more royal than Julie Andrews ever could have done. This was actually her last great performance and something of the crowning achievement of her stardom, before she turned to less glamorous parts, while Julie Andrews went on in her stardom as just a musical star.
Another great asset of major importance of the film is Cecil Beaton's fashionable settings, dressing everyone up to heavenly standards, already.visually stríking in the first scene and even more in the great Ascot scene. But the music is the crown jewel of this film, making it a crown jewel also of musicals, and Andre Previn's orchestration adds further lustre to Frederick Loewe's music. He would never make music like this again, both "Gigi" and "Camelot" are inferior to "My Fair Lady", where every melody strikes home as unforgettable. In brief, this musical reached its ultimate pinnacle of success as a perfect film.

So many reviews on this site debate whether or not Julie Andrews should have been cast in the lead. Others analyze Shaw's intentions, his play, or the Broadway musical in delivering a verdict on the film. Such musings may be interesting, but they have nothing to do with the merits of this film. It is a piece of art that stands on its own.As such, I feel that "My Fair Lady" is one of the best film musicals ever made. Audrey Hepburn is perfectly suited to the role of Liza. Most of her singing was dubbed, so we will never know if Hepburn herself had the chops to convincingly sing the entire part. But I find her acting wonderful.Liza Doolittle is a Cockney flower girl who seems content with her dirty life in the street. It should be noted that "the street" in this film is on a sound stage. And it is not really dirty, though Liza's cheeks might be dirtied somewhat. This is no gritty representation of real life. As with most musicals, there is an element of cleanliness that might suggest derivation from the stage. Hepburn captures the essence of the young woman with her howling speech and her readiness to battle over any perceived slight.Henry Higgins (played by Rex Harrison) is a snooty academic who jousts with other academics over minor variations in regional speech patterns. He accepts a wager from his associate, Colonel Pickering, promising he can transform the dirty guttersnipe into a refined woman fit for high society.Over a period of time, Higgins schools and browbeats Liza until he has indeed created a reasonable representation of refinement. But underneath the façade, Liza has the same personality.The music created by Lerner and Loewe is "loverly", even the parts designed for Higgins, which Harrison mostly singsongs rather than sings.The film won 8 Academy Awards. The staging is excellent. The costuming is superb.The "Ascot Gavotte" number is sheer perfection and deserves special mention. The upper crust are assembled trackside, watching the race. Presenting a frozen tableau, they deliver an emotionless, clipped description of their own excitement and the "frenzy" of the race. This is understated humor at its best. The men wear gray suits and hats, while the women are bedecked in exquisite gowns and hats of black and white. At the conclusion of the race, they execute a precision promenade that is choreographed perfectly. As they pivot and prance, they narrowly avoid one collision after another--more wonderfully subtle humor. Finally, Hepburn floats onto the scene, dressed in a black and white ensemble that somehow rises above the others. Holding her head erect with that impossibly graceful neck, she is the regal Nefertiti or a personification of a beautiful swan.The story presents a clever plot device in the character of Zoltan Karpathy, a Hungarian linguist with an impeccable reputation for divining the regional roots of any speaker. Can Liza pass for English society despite Karpathy's detective work?After the experiment is over, and the wager decided, what will become of Liza? With no work skills other than selling flowers, must she go back to the streets? Having used her for his academic purposes, will Higgins abandon her? Does he even have the emotional capacity to consider her feelings?"My Fair Lady" is a beautifully staged film filled with wonderful moments. I rate it "10".
Compared to its competition at Oscars, i.e. Dr Strangelove by Kubrick, this film is only ok. Rex Harrison, despite being quite good in this one, didn't deserve the Oscar above Sellers.

My Fair Lady is only surpassed by Sound of Music. It is a marvelous film. George Bernard Shaw loved women, and many of his plays have this contest of wills between them. Any the music and words are so clever, and the melodies so beautiful. When people say they don't like this, it means they don't like musicals. 1964 is a few years before the peak of western civilization, we haven't anything of this quality in decades, perhaps only Into the Woods reaches this level in the last 30 years. James Welch Henderson Arkansas 4/7/2021.

reviews.review_title: A shining musical example - but no-one makes them any more
reviews.content: Well, this is definitely my favourite musical. Forty years after it was released it still sparkles. The negative was restored in 1994 and it was a new print that I saw recently on TV. In devising the lyrics Alan J Lerner stuck fairly closely to the original "Pygmalion" script, thus much as Shaw would have hated it, his astringent words are sung as much as they are spoke. The movie is virtually the 1956 stage musical filmed, but George Cukor gives it a sheen a Broadway producer would be hard put to emulate (not to mention real horses at Ascot).Rex Harrison as Higgins was as I remember him, supremely self-confident and self-centred, with very hardworking eyebrows. But Audrey Hepburn as Eliza, who is not a very convincing flower girl, is more beautiful than I remember, and she is a real lady when the time comes for her to be one. There is almost too much Alfred Doolittle, though he has a couple of the best songs, but the great music hall veteran Stanley Holloway has the role down pat. As for the rest of the cast, they are all fine.My only beef is about the ending. In "Pygmalion" as first produced as a play in 1914, Eliza does not return to Henry Higgins, but goes off to marry the handsome, love-struck but vacuous Freddy. Shaw explained this in a postscript. When "Pygmalion' was filmed by Gabriel Pascal in 1937, this ending was altered so that in the last scene so that Eliza appears at the doorway just as Henry is hunting for his slippers. Shaw, it seems, hated this but permitted it because at least there was the possibility she might not stay.
