Typically, Hepburn would usually play roles which were closer to the "straight woman" in her comedic performances in films such as Funny Face and Love in the Afternoon, but here she fully embraces the largeness and ebullience of her character and plays her quite exceptionally. Hepburn reaches the apotheosis of her skill for comedic acting during a scene set at the Ascot horse race. It represents something of a crossroads moment in Eliza's transformation and, for my money, provides one of the most hilarious moments in cinematic history. The one criticism that was labelled at Hepburn in this film was that she didn't do her own singing. This is a shame, especially as her voice was certainly much better than her co-star's, who famously couldn't sing a note and therefore talked his way through his musical numbers. Marnie Nixon (the woman who would famously dub around 90% of Hepburn's singing) absolutely had the classically trained voice but I think the film would've benefited from a less perfect yet more authentic singing voice *ahem, Hepburn's*. Nonetheless, Hepburn is responsible for so much undeniable quality in the performance that it seems churlish and, ultimately, nit-picking to focus on a dubbing decision that was taken out of her hands.As to Holloway, he shines in every moment that he is on the screen. Playing the epitome of the lovable rogue archetype, his character is unashamedly venal and idle, in fact, he venerates his personal faults to the point of philosophic profundity. Holloway's physical mannerisms and off-the-cuff delivery also add touches of brilliance to a truly remarkable character display. All the other cast members put in stellar efforts too. Harrison has understandably become synonymous with his role as Henry Higgins as he invests his character with conviction, energy and just the right level of callousness, and Wilfrid Hyde-White balances Harrison's harshness with a compassionate, avuncular tenderness that just about allows Eliza to survive her professor's training.All in all, this is a brilliant piece of film making which still maintains its full capacity to entertain almost 60 years after its release. Its subject matter may be dated and its fundamental premise questionable to some but its story still resonates. After all, from classic stories such as Cinderella and The Ugly Duckling to reality TV shows such as America's Next Top Model and Queer Eye, makeover stories have been, and will continue to be, told for time immemorial, and My Fair Lady is certainly among the best of them.

reviews.review_title: There are no others to match Rex Harrison and Aubrey Hepburn for this show
reviews.content:
I have seen several versions and recordings of MY FAIR LADY and none come a patch up to the two main Stars of the show
There could never be another to reach or surpass Rex Harrison as Professor Higgins
Aubrey Hepburn is outstanding as Eliza Doolittle
Julie Andrews missed out here but I believe she did very well as Eliza in the stage show
In one way this movie could be compared to MAID IN MANHATTAN but it is an important point
We tend to look down on people when we are in a higher station
Jennifer Lopez makes a very accurate comment in Maid in Manhattan to Ralph Fiennes after she has been exposed as a Maid
She says he "saw" her but never noticed her when was she was cleaning the Bathroom
He only "Saw" as a person when she was "dolled" up to his stature
LikewIse Freddy did exactly the same when he first met Eliza after bumping into her and scattering all her Flowers
She was beneath him then so all he rendered her was courtesy and Help
When he met her at the Racetrack he never recognized her as the same woman he had knocked over
So it is in real life
If you the underdog you are nothing
You mean nothing in the world and are only there to serve others
Eliza had a dream to get out of her rut and become someone
She was determined to make something of herself and she most definitely did Reaching for the stars and overcoming adversity
Higgins just saw her as a challenge to make a woman out of her and it wa sonly when she finally stood up to him that he saw her in a completely different lightI am a seeker of hidden messages in movies and watch and Tewatch shows many times picking out hidden messages
This movie was great,
It had good music full of Humor and slickness
It showed how the Upppercrust was and the snobbishness that goes with the Upperclass people
But to me the most important messages I found with this movie is the sad acknowledgement of those below us and also that if you have a dream you must go for it
People need to stop watching movies just fr the sake of escapism And delve deeper into what the story is about and what we can learn from it
People, All People are People who are not just objects to be used and abused
All people from top to bottom should be recognized as being part of their lives and that they are contributing to other people's lives ether positively or negatively
People want to and Need to be acknowledged and Appreciated
By doing so we make this world a better place for us all

I loved this movie! Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison were magnificent! My favorite number from this movie is "Wouldnt it be Loverly". I love that one and find myself singing along every time! It was a little weird to hear Audrey with that accent in the beginning but I still loved it! I give this a 9/10!

Good things: Beautiful sets, decent songs, ok performances, Higgins is fairly funny, and an easy to follow story.Bad things: WAY too long, useless songs especially from the dad, Audrey Hepburn has one of the worst voices of all time in the fist half of the movie (I know this is on purpose, but my god), and Higgins is a huge ass.My biggest and worst complaint about this fine movie, is that the run time is bloated with useless musical numbers, this is a 1hr 50min movie tops, but because of Bollywood type musical numbers it (like a Bollywood movie) is bloated to 2hrs 50mins. I think it's perfectly fine, but with heavy flaws.

After reviewing this movie numerous times for an American Film class I have begun to love it even more than I had when I was a child. I grew up watching My Fair Lady and enjoyed it first through song. Now, I appreciate it for its history, creativity, and design. This movie really leaves an impression on the viewer towards the conclusion of the film. Cukor allows the audience to question Eliza and Higgins' thoughts and feelings throughout the entire movie; are they in love? or are they just a test for one another? Either way Cukor creates an atmosphere in which you can be creative with your imagination; so whether they have seen the plays or read the myths you can always end it however you please.

A movie from 1964, directed by George Cukor. Starring Audrey Hepburn, Rex Harrison and Stanley Holloway. The story of Eliza Doolittle, poor flower girl, and Henry Higgins, rich phonetics professor. Professor Higgins agrees to teach Eliza how to speak correctly in English. Both will have benefits of it: Eliza should find a better job, and professor Higgins will win a bet. The story is very simple but well written. Great acting, great music and great choreography. I liked it, but to be honest I was bored sometimes.

40th Minute, tears dropping.
Maybe more than twenty years have passed away since...
Certainly my English language skills aren't the same.
Maybe I am in need of a real spoken English teaching, all those marvelous accents I could have had been in contact except that I actually have not had the chance to meet them.
"For I, being poor..."
But today I prefer to spend my nothingness in, regarding such thrilling performances.
Because my teacher are you, distinguished participants of the commonly called cinema or, the broader sense of the seventh art.
It will be reviewed later, after watching it thoroughly.
Good riddance to those departed, to those alive, thriving, and especially godspeed to those initiating the path.
Thanks to G. Bernard Shaw, George Cukor, Rex Harrison, to all crew, and with honors, and a lot melancholy, to Audrey Hepburn.

Based on the Shaw play Pygmalion,  this great Broadway musical starred Julie Andrews, who for some reason is NOT in this film version, this musical still soars.  Filled with memorable songs and scenes, and featuring Rex Harrison in perhaps his greatest role, this is a touching musical about language and feeling. It sounds austere but it ain't. Go out and rent it!

reviews.review_title: Arguably, the best musical of all time.
reviews.content: MY FAIR LADY (1964)"You don't argue with success", so says the sleeve note of the original soundtrack recording of West Side Story. It is a relevant remark in the case of My Fair Lady too. I watched it for the n th time, and am sure that I would watch it again for the n+1 time also. What is the magic of My Fair Lady?Well, firstly, the music. It is brilliant. And the kind of "speaking song" that the Lerner-Loewe combination mastered even in Camelot, particularly suited the professor. Secondly, the way the relationship of professor and Eliza evolves, that is definitely based on a deep understanding and love for each other, but that never gets the word "love" out of any. Thirdly, the nostalgia that we, living in turbulent days, feel for those good old days. Not only the days portrayed in the film, but also the days of great musicals, the 50's and early 60's.The main criticism that was levelled against My Fair Lady was that it was theatrical. But on reflecting this issue, one realizes that the same theatricality effectively conveys the superficiality and the formality of the society that is depicted. This again increases the beauty of the Higgins-Eliza relationship.Way back in the sixties I thought it was the perfect film. In the seventies, I was afraid to see it again lest I should have out-grown the magic- and I was wrong. Now I am not afraid to see it again- because I am sure I will always love it. And arguably, it is the best musical of all time.

I've been scanning a lot of the comments for this movie, and they disappoint me. Julie Andrews was fantastic for the Broadway version--it's a shame she lost her voice. But Audrey Hepburn had something that made her My Fair Lady--a rare sort of dignity. Besides, Julie Andrews had to be Mary Poppins--and later, Fraulein Maria. Hepburn's transformation was half the fun of the movie--the other half was all thanks to Sir Rex Harrison. Prof. Henry Higgins is one of the few people I truly love to hate. He makes me laugh at the same time I'm calling him a heartless S.O.B. And it's obvious where he gets his biting tongue from--Mrs. Higgins is still one of my favourite characters. Freddy Ainsford Hill was touching, but saccharine. His song is one of my favourites, and Eliza's father never fails to make me grin. But the defining moment for me was the ending--Despite Henry's pretense that it doesn't matter, the loving smile on Eliza's face tells us of the happiness to come. All in all, this is one of my favourite movies. Bravo.

-My Fair Lady- is close to perfection if it isn't there. Some may dislike it because they dissent with George Bernard Shaw's premise that language is the most obvious sign of social class in 19th-century Britain. People could have lots of money and be 'low'; someone with the right sort of speech can fool others about one's origins. If one fails to accept this premise, then the movie fails miserably. I accept Shaw's premise that language is nearly everything. Rex Harrison excels in his role as 'Henry Higgins', a pedantic expert who believes that by changing the speech patterns of the lowliest flowermonger 'Eliza Doolittle' (Audrey Hepburn), who must surrender all of the certainties of her proletarian life (including getting away with her low-class speech) to prove her benefactor's theories true. Note well that any slipup in the role ensures that we see Higgins as an unspeakably cruel man performing an unethical experiment. Somehow one can believe his thesis that by changing the speech one can change everything and transform a flowermonger into a debutante -- but we must also feel Eliza's distress at the effort to change her. Sure, it's slow, as noted -- demonstrating how difficult a task Henry Higgins has given himself... and, of course, Eliza Doolittle. Clearly, Higgins has far less to lose than Doolittle. Changing thirty years of 'bad' habits doesn't come easily.What does the experiment achieve? Partial success. Maybe there is more to change than language, as at the horsetrack scene, where Eliza Doolittle charms the superficial characters of the upper crust with her trivialities, only to bring out her proletarian roots to the fore when she gets emotionally involved with the horse race {"Move your bloomin' @rse!").Finally, Eliza Doolittle gets exposed by one of Higgins' rivals, 'Zoltan Karpathy', (Theodore Bikel), who gets to hear the results of the experiment and concludes that she is a fake -- too good to be true as an Englishwoman! She must be --- Hungarian!Henry Higgins gives all the credit to himself, and none to the one who took the greater sacrifices for little assurance of benefits. That begins a course of events that lead in directions that he can't foresee (and which are spoilers).Is Audrey Hepburn too good to be true? Sure -- she was then spectacularly beautiful once one took her out of rags and put her into 'classier' attire. Could Higgins have succeeded with an older, less-attractive woman? I doubt it. Shaw's contention that language is everything -- more than the content of one's thoughts, more than money, more than years of habits, and more than attractiveness isn't 100% true. But it's close!.

The movie is about a story between aflower- girl Eliza and a gentleman Higgins.Eliza was a fair but poor girl who had a distinct countryside accent.Higgins was alinguist professor.He bet with his friend Pickering that he could teach Eliza for 6 months and transform her into a lady.Finally they succeed while Eliza left because of theselfishness of Higgins.
This film in some way reflects the social hypocrisy andvanity, a standard accent can reflect a person by birth and education, but not asthe only standard. Society worship of beauty and temperament, the professor had the opportunity to build a flower girlyoung become socialite.

It's a timeless classic, and while some may nit-pick at some aspects, My Fair Lady proved its greatness by landing a spot on the American Film Institute's Top 100 Films list. While it's true that Audrey Hepburn's singing was dubbed by Marnie Nixon, she delivers a strong, although not solid performance.  While some of her lines, especially towards the end, seemed artificial, I still sympathized with her. Sir Rex Harrison, the original stage Henry Higgins, performs as well as always here.  His fast-paced, dialogue-packed songs are as loaded as gunfire and very entertaining. Alfred P. Doolittle, the dustman, is a timeless favorite, and his "Little Bit O' Luck" and "Get Me to the Church on Time" numbers are whimsical and natural. While My Fair Lady is considered a romance, as so many big-budget film musicals were at the time, you'll see not a single kissing scene or anything really that romantically inclined.  Bernard Shaw's play, Pygmalian (which upon the movie is based) is a metaphor for the artist who falls in love with his creation.  In this case, Higgins is the creator, Eliza, the "flar garl" turned princess, his creation.  Whether it is truly love he eventually feels for her or pure admiration, it's hard to say.  But ultimately the film is almost three hours of innocent fun.

The George Cukor directed "My Fair Lady" (1964) was on our local classics channel. I realize how wonderfully hard the cast worked to make a great film, an even greater musical. Audrey Hepburn (Eliza), Rex Harrison (Professor Higgins) and Wilfrid Hyde-White (Colonel Pickering) joined together against their adversary Theodore Bikel (Zoltan Karpathy) showing him, he didn't know didn't know everything. Henry does the training but Eliza does all the work in the learning department.The costumes/make-up, from Eliza's dirty face and old dress to the later dresses (the teaching scenes) and especially, the gowns (for Ascot and, later, the ball), are breath-taking. Costume designer Cecil Beaton, and his staff, did a stupendous job.Thanks to director of photography, Harry Stradling lightening from the market scene to Ascot to the Grand Duchesses Ball to the end is well done.Then there is the original, expressive music by Frederick Loewe. All Eliza Wanted "Was a Room Somewhere". Henry wanted to know "Why Can't a Women Be More Like a Man". Hugh liked to dance to the "Rain in Spain". Freddy had "Often Walked Down this Street Before". Eliza ended her role "Without You" (referring to Henry). All of the music is beautiful.Henry proclaims Eliza FREE of him by her own independent speech. Then, after he leaves her, he expresses his own agony at realizing he may have lost her. He'd grown "Accustomed to Her Face". So what is next?I saw it in 1964 after reading "Pygmalion". "My Fair Lady" was much better. Much more interesting.It's three hours long but it doesn't drag. Story and music sails right along. I hope everybody gets to see it.

My Fair Lady is a great movie with unforgettable music, stars, costumes, and sets. Audrey Hepburn is a lovely and talented actress and she does a fine job as Eliza Doolittle. I think, however, that she was too 'delicate' for the role, and I was, for the first and only time disappointed with Miss Hepburn's performance. In all honesty, I admit my prejudice for having twice seen Julie Andrews' spectacular performance on Broadway.

reviews.review_title: I have a little spoiler>> We accept the Cinderella story without any resistance. I think we have to take this movie more seriously.
reviews.content: Pick up your slipper, Do it yourself.Many women see the Cinderella story as they grow up from childhood including me. And we dream that fallen in love after meeting the prince. This memory that we are absorbed without any resistance for a long time was left in the unconscious mind even we reach manhood. This being so, I think we have to read or see this story with seriousness. Eliza Doolittle lives in a London and poor young flower-seller. She speaks in heavy dialect. While Professor Higgins belongs to the upper class and studies the language and accents. He and his friend make a bet on whether she can be a lady or not. And Higgins assures he can make her to this. He feels love to Eliza while teaching her. Though they have some troubles, Eliza takes his heart.When I finished "My fair lady", I can't embrace this story that left some questions. How Eliza accepts herself who is made by others, NOT HERSELF! And how we understand Higgins feels love for a girl who is created by him. Does Higgins have right to look down on Eliza who just speaks in dialect. Can we call a gentleman like this guy? My fair lady doesn't reply to these questions. They just give an answer for romance. That's why I prefer the original play "Pygmalion" of George Bernard Shaw than My fair lady. They have almost same contents except a crucial difference. A heroine of the Pygmalion closes her mind to Higgins at least in the author's intention. Is it a sad-ending? But she just chooses herself instead of man's love. I send my congratulations to her.Even if "My fair lady" is an interesting story that got a widely loved until now, I think we never take this story for granted. We have to find and ask some problems in this story over the simple amusement. You sense very tiresome and difficult, but you can look more pleasure. In that sense, it had time to think about relationship of men and women, love, and something that form me once more.

reviews.review_title: Should be available to watch or buy
reviews.content:
This is a fantastic Audrey Hepburn movie musical it should be available to watch or buy
The chemistry between her and Rex Harrison is wonderful

Catchy tunes, fancy costumes, elaborate production and sharp dialogue occasionally lifted straight from Shaw's play, make this one of the best Musicals of the decade. Then, at the last minute, everything goes inexplicably wrong. The whole concept of making "Pygmalion" into a love story did not feel right from the start: the play itself had a different ending. Why have Eliza (Audrey Hepburn at her most glamorous), reverse her rightful decision to leave her (tor)mentor Higgins (Rex Harrison, at his most eloquent). In the end, she is reduced to the same kind of brainless twit she was always accused of being. It's funny, but on a personal note, "My Fair Lady" was the only movie to ever make me cry (at the age of 10, mind you) , because of my frustration with the final scene. Having not yet reached puberty, I had no option but to view Higgins (a charming bastard, who sometimes makes more than a bit of sense) as a shameless pig. "Love is blind", was my mother's impromptu attempt to calm me down. It may be so, but still, I would have liked Eliza to emerge from her training sessions a more empowered creature.

Yes, My Fair Lady is excellent and very enjoyable; but, let's start out with the casting. For years afterward, the rumors kept going on about Julie Andrews not making the film and that Jack Warner's explanation that she wasn't well enough know to make the movie was poor judgment on Warners part, but now that we see the movies years later, it seems that Warmer was right at the time, and even Rex Harrison was known to say that Audrey Hepburn would make a delightful Eliza on the seine. Hepburn would not make the movie because she felt that Julie Andrews should, but when Andrews was out of the running, Audrey Hepburn agreed to play Eliza on the screen. When asked how she had the nerve to play Eliza on the screen, she answered that it wasn't that she had the never to play Eliza, it was that she didn't have the nerve to turn it down. The dubbing of Marni Nixon with Audreys partial singing is O.K., but they should had Audrey do most of the singing and let Nixon, or someone else, take over some of the higher notes that Hepburn couldn't reach.Now, how about Eliza's father Alfred? In James Cagney's autobiography, he relates that George Cukor contacted him to see if he'd play the role, and Cagney after much hem-hawing said something to the effect, "Everything about My Fair Lady is so fine; one hell-uh-vuh song and dance show. Maybe, just maybe, one more time." But then he told Cukor to go on without him. That he was in retirement and just couldn't get worked up to do it. So, they went ahead, but wouldn't it have been something that if Cagney DID do it, he would have got his second Oscar of a song and dance man since he won for playing George M. Cohan in "Yankee Doodle Dandy". Every time I see the movie, I can just see Cagney singing "Get Me To The Church On Time".Basically, the film is fine, but there seems to be something missing from it. Maybe too long? Couldn it have been shortened? Sometimes it seems like it's dragging, sometimes not. I can't explain it, but there is something missing that makes it from an excellent musical film to a classic that it should be, but nevertheless, it's loverly as it is!On the down side, again, it's strange that Julie Andrews won the Oscar that year for Mary Poppins and Rex Harrison for My Fair Lady, and Audrey Hepburn was not even mentioned for her work in My Fair Lady with the excuses that you couldn't understand her in the first half and that she didn't do her own singing which partially she really did! Oh, well, that's Hollywood for you, but if Julie Andrews had done My Fair Lady on the screen, then we wouldn't have had Mary Poppins or, what was that little movie musical she did about some Nuns and a Captain? Strange how things work out in the end for the betterment of all; isn't it?

reviews.review_title: It is impossible to fault this movie but to add a comment
reviews.content:
This exquisite, incomparable musical in its movie form was of course controversial because they cast Hepburn instead of Andrews.  And then of course had to dub Hepburn (I think Marnie Nixon deserves the National Medal of Freedom or some such recognition, if she's still alive).
Hepburn never made a bad movie or gave a bad performance.  She was the epitome of elegance in all her movies and I loved her as much as any of you, but: there is one tiny flaw in this otherwise majestic movie.  Has anyone else noticed that after the embassy ball, Eliza does not in fact speak the King's English?  She speaks with Hepburn's own elegant but not entirely native accent.  (Hepburn was Belgian and grew up speaking French and Flemish).  The "k" sound is just a bit wrong.  Ironic, no?

I realize that that line is probably used a whole lot, but it fits so well with this movie. It's about a flower girl named Eliza Doolittle. She is a common flower girl, nothing special, and that's why a Professor Higgens jots her down in visible speech. He boasts to a Colonel Pickering that within 6 months, he could pass her off as a Duchess at an embassy ball.
She takes him up on that boast, and for six months, he constantly Hammers into her head how to speak correctly, which turns out quite an adventure for him. They make progress, but when tried in public, she embarasses herself immensly. And there's only 6 more weeks until the ball. Time's ticking...This is a wonderful movie, with great songs, lots of laughs, a few D- words, alright, a little more than a few. Higgens uses them quite frequently, but it's quite overlooked. You see the struggle that Eliza goes through, and you just have to stay with her until the end. If you watch this movie, you will truly be enchanted by it. I'm saying this and I'm a boy. Get yourself over to your nearest DVD dealer. Come on! Go! MOVE YOUR BLOOMIN' -!

My Fair Lady would have to be one of the most stagey, stilted, artificial, chocolate-box looking films ever made. George Cukor directs traffic, rather than makes cinema. But God I love it! The music, the performers, (Wilfred Hyde-White I love you) and the Shavian wit. I think this is one stage musical that cried out NOT to be opened out, but to be shot AS a stage musical. And thank God that's what Cukor and Jack Warner thought too.

The movie had the elegant Audrey Hepburn.  She was timid, she was beautiful, she did everything to be Ms. Doolittle.  All the acting was good. Perfect, such a mood that you do not want it to leave the screen.  I would give it a ten.  The music was good.  I must say that this was one of the all-time musicals.

reviews.review_title: One of the great musicals--and one of the great miscastings
reviews.content: I first saw this film on its original release and have seen it at least a dozen times since. It's a superb film version of one of the very finest musical ever written. Consider: one of George Cukor's best efforts as director; Rex Harrison, Stanley Holloway, Gladys Cooper, Jeremy Brett, Wilfred Hyde-White, Theodore Bikel, Mona Washbourne, as good as cast as you ever might get; Cecil Beaton costumes; some of the most splendid art direction ever; and that wonderful score.Why a seven, then? One of the great miscastings, that's why. Audrey Hepburn is like a void in the role of Eliza. She never gets the cockney accent on the first hour. Post-accent, she is just confused--sentimental and shrewish by turns. If Warner had had any gumption, they would have cast Julie Andrews, who owned the role. And it isn't an easy role, either--I saw a revival of Pygmalion some years ago with Amanda Plummer, who also failed to get the role at all.The musical's departure from Shaw--putting Higgins together with Eliza--has always always struck me as sentimental twaddle which makes nonsense of the underlying themes of the play. It fits Hepburn's performance--unfortunately. And then there is the dubbing from Marnie Nixon, the Great American Voice. Partly because of this, Hepburn's acting in the musical numbers verges on the painful.It's very unfortunate that Harrison's performance--one of the great ones of the 20th century--is saddled with Hepburn's. Thank goodness the rest of the cast is worthy of Harrison.Is this Higgins' story, or Eliza's? Higgins', I think--much more obviously in the original play. That's why this is still a borderline great movie--the casting of Eliza can't completely ruin it. But it knocks a good 30% off the rating.Of course you should see it. But try to look past a sentimental view of Hepburn. In this--and indeed in most of her films, except two or three--she just isn't that good. She isn't even that charming--just annoying.

George Cukor won the Academy Award for Best Direction of this film, and it isn't hard to understand why.  However, I believe that he was awarded it simply for his entire body (more than forty years?) of work than for this one film in particular.  My Fair Lady on stage ran for over 1,000 performances (a record in its day) and for the majority of the 1950's on Broadway and was Lerner and Loewe's first major triumph (to be followed by Camelot in 1960).  One of the biggest coups of the filming of this musical was the fact that the filmakers were able to secure two out of three of the original New York cast members when shooting the film.  We all know who they left out! Frankly, I cannot begin to admit that I thoroughly enjoyed My Fair Lady as a film musical (a dying breed by the way) because I really didn't.  Rex Harrison was phenomenal in the role of Professor Henry Higgins just as Yul Brynner was in The King and I.  We are fortunate enough that today we have both of their performances forever captured upon celluloid.  On the other hand, Julie Andrews has become so synonomous with the role of Eliza Doolittle that it basically had to be considered as a smack in the face for her not to be given the role when it transferred over onto film. It isn't that I dislike Audrey Hepburn, I like her alot, but in roles that she originated (like Holly Golightly and Sabrina Fair), not in roles that she assumed after the original had come and gone.  Stanley Holloway does a superb job as Eliza's "bum" of a father, Alfred P. Doolittle (a role he originated on Broadway as well).  Jeremy Brett brought pathos and heartfelt conviction to the role of Freddy Eynsford-Hill, Eliza's love interest.If anything was wrong with the film itself as a story, the amount of time between each musical number was almost excruciatingly unbearable.   Then, once we got to a musical number, two were usual done back to back, the highlights for me being "Wouldn't it be Loverly", "I Could Have Danced All Night" and of course the perennial favorite love song, "On the Street Where You Live".  I assume that Cukor was attempting to make up for lost time.  
The overall "look" of the film was done quite beautifully by Mr. Cecil Beaton (who had also designed the original Broadway production in 1954). The costuming and settings were exquisite down to the minutest details.  I especially loved the main title sequence with the background of the fresh floral arrangements.Both Harrison and Hepburn were up for Academy Awards for their performances with Harrison winning and Hepburn being beaten by Julie Andrews (of all people) for Walt Disney's Mary Poppins.  Ah yes, I guess revenge can be sweet when done the right way.For a musical comedy of such magnitude and one that defined an era as this one did, I hear that the bidding for the screen rights to this musical were quite high.  After finally seeing this film in one sitting I can't help but ask myself why?  After all, it won eight Academy Awards in 1964 including Best Picture (something that should have gone to Mary Poppins that year if you ask me), but I still can't help but think that only three people deserved them wholeheartedly: Cecil Beaton, Rex Harrison and last but definitely not least the late, great George Cukor who with this take on a Broadway Musical Masterpiece finally achieved true Hollywood legendary status!  Bravo, George!My rating: 2 and a half stars, simply because of the fact that this film should have been made with the original, the most fairest lady of them all: Miss Julie Andrews.  Who did Audrey Hepburn think she was anyway?

Misogynistic and classist, 1964's Best Film winner should be taken in context. While it is a fine musical, it is also a bright and witty comedy with some wonderful performances. Although it was Rex Harrison who picked up the film's sole acting Oscar, neither Stanley Holloway nor the impossibly beautiful Audrey Hepburn would have been undeserved winners.
Hepburn shines as the flower seller who, under Harrison's strict tutorage blossoms into an elegant and lovely young lady. Holloway, as ne'er-do-well, Alfred P. Doolittle steals every scene he is in.In keeping with many musicals of the time, the film is shot entirely in a studio, and, in truth, this does detract from the film's look. However, it remains a great musical, with many memorable songs. A fine score and Audrey Hepburn; who can ask for more?

reviews.review_title: Sir Rex Harrison has no peer!
reviews.content: Has there ever been an actor as completely watcxhable as the wonderful Sir Rex Harrison? His performance in my Fair Lady will always bee onee of the all time greats! As with Gable in "Gone With The Wind", Yul Brynner in "King and I' and Brando and Leigh in "Streetcar, Harrison's Henry Higgins is a legend. He brings such a quality to the role making you sympatise,while also making you say "What an arrogant S.O.B.!"He won a well deserved Oscar for the film against some stiff competition including Burton and O'Toole in "Becket". The rest of the cast is nothing to sneeze at either. The great Stanley Hollowy and the ever watchable Wilfred Hyde White lending ever enjoyable support along with Gladys Cooper as Higgin's long suffering Mother. Hepburn could have been better,but why complain.She is good enough for the role,and besides...its Sir Rex's film anyway. So sit back and enjoy This legendary actor in his most famous role!

reviews.review_title: One of the best musicals ever!
reviews.content: Hepburn is at her best along with the Rex Harrison...  for the light comic love story that it is, it's among the best... a "must see", as it sets the pace for most romantic comedies of our generation, except with great musical "interludes", if you will that are sure to put a beat to your heart.  "Why can't a woman be more like a man?"

Lerner and Loewe's classy and witty songs make this the perfect musical. Rex Harrison, is, as always, fabulous recreating his broadway role. Audrey Hepburn makes a perfect Eliza Doolittle, even if her singing is dubbed. If you don't crack up at the song "Why can't a woman be more like a man," something's wrong.

Family film night and this month we're watching Oscar best picture winners. Starting with a pre-1970 family choice which was unfortunately a bit of a shocker. In my memory this was a much better film. Audrey Hepburn is unmatchably awful in the first hour. I've no idea what accent she was attempting. I don't understand why history has damned Dick Van Dyke grief for his 'cockerney' accent and not her. To make matters worse she doesn't even sing the songs, they were dubbed by Marni Nixon. To be fair it does have some banging songs, the costumes are fabulous and Rex Harrison's monsterous performance is pitch perfect even if his 'singing' isn't. The sexual politics have not aged well, it goes on for ever and the last hour drags to a horrible ending. Jess got more and more annoyed as the film progressed. To think this beat both Mary Poppins and Dr Strangelove to Best Picture in 1965 is 'rather disappointing'. (That last comment was censored by Sarah) Scored 5/10 and is the lowest scoring so far of our 50 family film nights choices.

This movie is a delight! From start to finish, the cast, the sets, the costumes, the music, the direction of George Cukor, and the story all make for an excellent movie. This is first rate entertainment, done with sytle and great attention to detail.  From the outset, the movie, especially the cast, weaves an enchanting spell - one fit for youngsters of all ages. But as the story unfolds, the viewer find that there is serious material and a lesson in this story. . The movie questions our values of class, gender, love, roles in relationships, and self worth. All this is put to the wonderful music of Lerner and Lowe, and superb performances by the cast. Rex Harrison, Stanley Holloway and Wilfrid Hyde-White are the very essence of their characters.  Miss Hepburn's performance seems strained at times, but this is easily overlooked by perfection in almost everything, including costumes, lighting, and set direction. Yet, for all the character's and overall charm of this movie, you'll find yourself questioning your values at the end of it, and find that the answer is delivered with love, in a most beguiling story set in an enchanted setting. Don't miss this one!

I watched this film 2 nights ago all the way through and it's very good, the songs are good and well sung (even though Audrey Hepburn had her voice dubbed as she can't sing). And the storyline is even better, I have never seen the stage play but I'm sure it's just as good, maybe better! Towards the end however I was beginning to waver and started to think, 'How much longer?' it is a bit long at 2 hours and 45 minutes and there were some bits which could have been cut out for a bit shorter viewing. I suppose the intermission was to state it was really a play, but it wasn't that necessary I don't think. Anyway I gave this film a 6 and I recommend it to everyone who loves musicals.

I reckon this is a must see for every person of any age, even those who don't generally enjoy musicals. It is hilariously entertaining and enjoyable to watch again and again. Audrey Hepburn is a great actress and portrays Eliza Dolittle in a unique way. There is a variety of different characters, all very likable in their own ways. After watching the film, I found I could understand comedies that used the storyline, such as in Family Guy, when the Drunken Clam burns down and we meet Nigel and Eliza Pinchley, and in The Simpsons when Sideshow Bob sings 'Accustomed to (his) face'. The songs are very catchy, I found myself singing them and quoting lines from the film. If performing a theatre or play version of My Fair Lady I advise that the film is seen before. I personally don't think I will ever get bored of watching the spectacular acting and singing skills.

reviews.review_title: They Don't Make 'Em Like This Anymore...
reviews.content: The flowers. Audrey. The songs...oh, the songs! There's nothing quite like hearing "On The Street Where You Live"...the ultimate musical expression of love...this is an amazing movie if only for the aesthetic value. But the acting is superb as well. The film just has this marvelously witty, warm, adult quality; this is no movie for small minds or the naive...there is a lot of social commentary, warring of the sexes, and one of the oddest yet most endearing 'love' stories around. Rex Harrison (reprising his Broadway role) is perfect. The supporting cast is awesome. The costumes! The flowers! Audrey! The songs! Watch this movie and simply smile & enjoy yourself. They don't make 'em like this anymore.

It's a wonderful movie that is beautifully acted and skillfully directed. I did, however, find a flaw with one of the lesser characters. That being the character of Freddy, of whom I found to be one dimensional and undeveloped. I think the film would of been just as good or probably even better without that certain character. It was  Unnecessary because I found that he was just there to be an emotional crutch for Audrey Hepburn's character. Rex Harrison is perfect and has a great singing. Hepburn is also very convincing, as is Stanley Holloway. Despite that one flaw, it is still a great film.

This Film is wonderful funny, Hepburn is great as Eliza Doolittle and everything about this film is great: the screenplay, actor, director, songs, story, clothes just everything, everybody who love musicals and Audrey Hepburn or George Cukor or somebody else of the cast/crew Must see it, absolutely one of the best musicals ever.

reviews.review_title: It's an Audrey Hepburn movie, of course it's excellent!
reviews.content: This is a great movie, and one of the last great film musicals.  Audrey Hepburn was as always charming and enchanting.  Rex Harrison made the role of Henri Higgins his and his alone.  My only criticism is that the ending could have provided more of a closure.  The songs will be stuck in your head long after you finish watching the movie.

as many of my peers(OLD FARTS),,i had the pleasure of seeing this play on Broadway,,and when it opened on the big screen,,when i found it to be on TV tonight(SATURDAY,10/20/07),i just had to see it one more time.i have read some of the numerous comments posted,and offer this..the comparisons made between julie Andrews and Audrey Hepburn,may or may not be true.the commentators have their opinions,whether we agree with them or not.the "play",on stage or screen is truly what its all about.the memories brought back to me while watching tonight,were,,to me the joy of seeing this "show",again.my thanks to the turner classic movie channel.movies like this are rarely seen by our younger generation,and i bear responsibility,for allowing this to happen.to all the old farts who read my comments,,make your grandchildren aware of this film,and so many others like it..thank you

This is one of the greatest musicals of all time.Audrey Hepburn shone as Eliza Dolittle, although her accent was a little strange at the beginning.But the star of the show has to be Rex Harrison in the role of Professor Henry Higgins.  It is easy to see that he was born to play this part and his acting is invisible.My favourite songs are "The Rain in Spain" and "On the Street Where You Live".Definitely a 10/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the great movie musicals
reviews.content: This is one of the great movie musicals, with a fantastic score and a witty book that owes a lot to George Bernard Shaw. I rate it a 9 or 10. Rex Harrison owns his role, thus carrying much of the film (the way Yul Brynner carries "The King and I" or Robert Preston carries "The Music Man"). Stylish direction, as usual, from Cukor. The one flaw is Audrey Hepburn's lack of singing -- her songs are actually sung by Marni Nixon. Nothing against Hepburn, but one wonders how Julie Andrews would have shone in the film.

reviews.review_title: Technical Error in Movie - Also Information Request
reviews.content: It seems a shame to point out a technical error in such a great movie. However, I have seen many tapes of races from Ascot Race Course and I can certify that at Ascot the races are run Clockwise, on what the British call a "Right Handed Course". In the movie's scene at Ascot Race Course, the horses are obviously running Counterclockwise, on what the British call a "Left Handed Course". To the best of my knowledge, the only times that horses actually run Counterclockwise at Ascot are while warming up before a race and while returning to be unsaddled.On another matter: Whoever is dubbed in as the singer for Jeremy Britt's "On the street where you live" is a very well trained tenor. So far I have been unable to find out who the artist is. Can anyone help me?

reviews.review_title: Pygmalion set to music, in color
reviews.content: On a whim, an aristocratic self focused London based bachelor bets he can impart his bearing, diction and manners to a poor cockney flower girl only to lose his heart in the gamble. Harrison is perfect, oozing sophisticated wit and condescension as the urbane gentleman while Hepburn is sublime as a gorgeous guttersnip that blossoms into an irresistible lady, a match for her teacher. The supporting cast is outstanding. The gold standard in musicals with several enduring classic songs. A chick flick that romantics of both sexes can enjoy.Based on the George Bernard Shaw play Pigmalion and music & lyrics by Let er and Lorwe.

I loved this movie, it was wonderful and the characters were developed well and the music was perfect. I've always loved the soundtrack, I knew it before I'd even seen the film, BUT the ending to this 1964 version was absolutely horrendous. It completely undoes the entire film, and it should have ended before Eliza came back. They really should have stuck with the original ending. She only comes back to be Henry's slave!! It makes everything that she says to him before hand mean nothing. This is probably the worst ending I've ever seen to any film, and it's so frustrating cause the rest of the film is so amazing.

This movie's plot is phenomenal. Eliza Doolittle's transformation was really miraculous, considering her background (though I loved the scene on the racetrack). Filled with humor and fabulous music, no one should miss this movie!

This movie is the first that made me realize that the Oscar is not infallible. Compare it to MARY POPPINS, and then tell me that MP is not the better movie by LIGHTYEARS! The direction is dull and uninspired; you get the impression that Cukor just nailed the camera to the floor, and then asked the actors to move in front of it. Hepburn is too elegant to be convincing in the title role. The acting of the others is mechanical; Pauline Kael opined that Rex Harrison played Henry Higgins one time too many; the same can be said of the other actors, who look bored and distracted. Only Stanley Holloway shows any zest in his role, and his performance is fatally sabotaged by the poor staging of his two big numbers, WITH A LITTLE BIT OF LUCK and GET ME TO THE CHURCH ON TIME. Indeed, the choreography of this show is so generally poor and unimaginative that you will wonder whether this is really a musical. Remember THE MUSIC MAN: now that IS choreography! Altogether, we are talking about a movie so dismal and boring that I have never had the courage to watch it a second time, quite unlike MARY POPPINS, which I have watched a dozen times. So, be warned: don't believe the four stars that TV GUIDE regularly--and inexplicably--gives this film. This is a FIASCO that does not deserve them!

reviews.review_title: A perfect 10...and I don't usually like musicals
reviews.content: Any one of the many musical routines could be the highlight of most any other musical.  I have to hand it to to the writers, the lyrics where not only applicable to the storyline, but absolutely hysterical.The casting was superb, the storyline charming and the insightful philosophy of papa Doolittle an absolute riot.  Do yourself a favor and watch this film some day, or watch it again.

I loved My Fair Lady I think that Audrey plays every part in this movie both elegantly and hillariously. I think that of all the actress's in the world audrey could play any part in any movie, she always seems to fit the charecter perfect,especially in romance films. She has class and elegance. Everytime you put in one of her films it makes you wish you were her, and you cant help but watch the movie again and again!

This film is refreshing!  With all the blood, guts, and sex on the screen these days, it is great to see a good clean movie.  It is nice to hear good music as well.  Music that does not give you a smashing headache!  My Fair Lady is a great musical comedy.  Hepburn is incredibly attractive in this film, both physically, and characteristically.

reviews.review_title: A True Classic That Never Ages
reviews.content: How many films can be just as fresh and enjoyable after nearly 60 years as they were the first time you saw them? I loved My Fair Lady when I saw it "first run" in the theater, as a matter of fact we had the Broadway cast album and I played it endlessly. So watching it now after many years, knowing every line of every song, and marveling over the sharpness of the lyrics again (as well as the dialogue) was such a treat. And of course, the sweetness of the music completes the musical package.There is no way a person can watch this only one time and take everything in. For example, during the scene at Ascot you want to look at each of the fabulous black and white costumes, and those wild hats. But if you do, you'll miss the hysterically dry humor of the lyrics.And speaking of costumes, when Hepburn appears on the stairs in that incredible ball gown, has anyone ever looked more gorgeous in any movie?They stopped making movies like this a long time ago.

reviews.review_title: Biting satire meets happily ever after
reviews.content: This glossy adaptation of George Bernard Shaw's 1913 play, Pygmalion, puts a sunny shine on the original tale of the phonetics professor who takes up the challenge of transforming an uneducated flower girl into a lady.  Based on what was originally Shaw's egotistical retort to being jilted by one of his young students, My Fair Lady shows a softer, more agreeable curmudgeon in Rex Harrison's portrayal of the crass Professor Higgins.  Opposite Harrison, Audrey Hepburns's performance of Eliza Doolittle, who seems to ooze a bit more charm than her satirical Pygmalion counterpart, leaves the audience cheering for the poor girl.  Vocals by Marni Nixon are dubbed masterfully for Eliza Doolittle.  There are striking scenes using color, such as the opening day at Ascot, and the tunes are clever and haunting.  "The Street Where You Live" is a personal favorite.  Some of Shaw's sharp wit is still intact in Jay Lerner's adaptive dialogue, but I recommend either reading or watching Pygmalion to those who appreciate Shaw's humor.

Everything about this film speaks talent. Even though that the real singer was so left out. She knew it. And Hepburn is about the only great star diva one ego who was not the leading motivation for denying a great voice her just due. The technicolor is so rich and so 60's and unforgettable for the 60's version of movies. We should be mindful that great stories played out in so rich ways can not be captured and shared on TV and small screens. We will either save big screens as we can collectively or we will all have our own vivid screens in our living rooms, losing a common ground. This is our last opportunity. We all hear this every day but when I see that there is no passion for the loss of the Metro here in SF, I think I must be either crazy or the whole world has lost every sense of culture. Do we really need another drugstore? Or even another great Borders? What I have come to realize is that the same people I admire for their love of movies hate the idea that there may be another big theater to compete with. Where is G. Lucas? He can build bricks in the Presidio and yet not see that the Metro can be a bridge for all that has shined before and will be revealed and shared again?

The wife of a friend of mine loaned me her copy of this movie, and after one watch it became my favorite musical. The story is just divine, and is so enchanting that you hardly notice the time going by.  The performances are magnificent.  The correlation between the changes in the two main characters -- being of course, Hepburn and Harrison, is partcularly well done.  Ms. Doolittle goes from a "guttersnipe" seemingly in one frame, meaning that you notice the exact moment she finally "gets it" and begins to act like a lady. Harrison, who had obviously mastered this role with the years he portrayed it on Broadway, is infinitely more subtle.  The first time you watch it, you aren't sure of his feelings for Eliza until the moment he hears her voice after he thinks she's left him.  He says "Eliza!" with such emotion and displays such a look of utter joy on his face.  On repeated viewings you will be able to pick up little hints he had been dropping all along that pointed to the fact that he was smitten, but the first time around, the wonderfully woven tapestry of characters and songs do an effective job of distracting you from what may or may not be in the cards for Eliza Doolittle and Prof. Henry Higgins.  Why in God's name this movie is only at #244 on the 250 list is beyond me.  It is easily in MY top ten.

I had heard so much about this movie but figured it was a classic and may have been boring. I do like some classics but I'm of the new generation and things like violence take me before romance does. However, I absolutely fell in love with this movie and watched it so many times afterward in hopes of one time acting it out myself. I feel the acting is so much better than what we are offered today and it also leaves you wanting to watch it over and over again. One day I will be able act out Eliza Doolittle and only hope to do a wonderful piece the justice it deserves. I highly recommend this movie to anyone with a decent sense of taste. Silver
Great actors, wonderful music, classical plot... What else do you want? I believe it is number one musical of all time.

reviews.review_title: This movie spoiled a perfect record...
reviews.content: I absolutely detest musicals.  This film is the one exception that comes to mind.Audrey Hepburn, besides being one of the most beautiful women to ever grace the silver screen, gives one of the most memorable perforances of any actress that I've ever seen.If you have never had the pleasure of viewing this movie, your life is not complete!

Undoubtedly,everything in this movie was so superb,though there were somewhat confusions in film editing(in the middle and at the end of horse race scenery) and wrong expressions of Audrey in some points when she was singing"Just you wait" and "I could have danced all night".Only one shot that she did her own best was the time she could successfully pronounce "The Rain in Spain..".Anyway, Eliza should be around 21 as Colonel Pickering informed a police. But her look in this film was over 30.Maybe 35 up.If the producers had made this film 10 years before when Audrey was so real young and beautiful as Princess in"Roman Holiday","My Fair Lady" would have been the completely fairest lady of all time.

"MY FAIR LADY" never ceases to dazzle me even after years since I have seen it. Based on George Bernard Shaw's "PYGMALION", it did what few musical adaptations could pull off: Shine with brilliance and splendour in betterment of it's classical source. The sumptuousness of this film lies not in its scope or production values but in its delicious performances from all involved. Particularly in Rex Harrison's Prof. Higgins. I have always been of the belief that he was one of the greatest actors in British theater. Rather than tirelessly croon the songs,he seems to be talking to the music;using it as a vehicle. You would be hard pressed to think of any other actor who could even approach playing the role with the grace and tour de force that Harrison lent. It is the role that Rex will always be famous for which,unfortunatly, is why his film career thereafter was relatively erratic. The box office bomb "DOCTOR DOOLITTLE" is an example of this.For readers who still have not seen "MY FAIR LADY", its a tale about Miss Eliza Doolittle, a street peddling flower girl who is transformed into an elegant Lady by the ever arrogant misogynist Prof. Henry Higgins. "The Rain In Spain" and "Getting Married in the Morning" will standout in your mind for years to come. Audrey Hepburn plays Eliza with gusto. There was alot of flak caused by the casting of the late Ms. Hepburn over Julie Andrews who was a staple in the Broadway production. In retrospect,I am of the opinion that this choice was the correct one. Sure, Julie Andrews had the renowned voice that the songs required (Marnie Nixon dubbed the musical numbers in the film) but I think the success of "MARY POPPINS" would've diluted the freshness and fabric that comes with role of Eliza. Besides, Hepburn had a certain presence and spontaniety that the big screen requires. Her flair and dynamics in the role are superb. However,the supporting cast really shines.  I am astonished that Stanley Holloway was snubbed for Best Supporting Oscar to Peter Ustinov in the less seen "TOPAKI". His Alfred doolittle is one of the most flamboyant and affable characters in screen history. Ditto with Wilfred Hyde-White's performance of col. Pickering;the eternal gentleman who arranges the pact with Eliza and Prof. Higgins. Another standout is the "Show Me" duet between Eliza and Freddie Eynsford-Hill(Jeremy Brett). The horse race folly will also be remembered. The film is a must for those who enjoy splendid performances in the great cinematic tradition,this is a requirement.

reviews.review_title: Oh wouldn't it be loverly if movies were as lovely as this?
reviews.content: I have loved 'My Fair Lady' ever since I first saw it on the stage when I was nine years old; when I was ten, I got this video for Christmas and I adored it! Even though Audrey Hepburn was dubbed, they selected the right singer to use in dubbing her voice.  I didn't know until I had had this video a year that Audrey Hepburn was dubbed, that's how good a job they did.Overall, Audrey was beautiful in her performance.  I shall not ignore Rex Harrison's Henry Higgins, for he greatly deserved that Oscar for Best Actor! Even though he cannot sing, his talk-singing fits his character.  The chemistry between Audrey and Rex is superb.  The acting overall is great, and I love Mrs. Higgins! The costumes were breathtaking, the music was lovely, the cinematography excellent, oh, the great things to say of this musical.  I wish Hollywood would make more musicals!

A very fine movie, with as near as you can get theatre on the film screen, evident from the fact all principal actors were theatre/ musical perfomers of the time. Photography excellent and better then modern day pictures with equipment of 1963 quite an achievement. Best thing about this picture is continuity, subject matter grabs the audience attention without using visual effects, as is common in modern day pictures. One can only say this picture is a milestone in movie making and probably will not be repeated, and is a model in the forgotten art of making film musicals on a budget. Noted also acting abilities also of a higher standard of most actors today, quite evident in the performances. The more you watch this picture the more you will want to see it. It is to movie making what a Beethoven symphony is to music. Also noted that an audio cd is available of the original Broadway production with Julie Andrews (when she was 21), recorded nine days after the stage production began on March 24th 1956. Almost 50 years ago! Also the London stage production is available on audio cd recorded in 1958?.

reviews.review_title: Best Musical Film of all time...
reviews.content: The phenomenal Audrey Hepburn... The amazing Rex Harrison... Glorious singing, a tug-of-war with Love, and an eventual fabulous makeover... There is absolutely nothing better!!

A witty and touching musical, My Fair Lady shines 40 years after it was first made. It touches even the most cynical viewer with its warmth and humor. The film takes place in early twentieth century London, where it comments on love and class distinction. It follows flower-seller Audrey Hepburn as she makes a deal with a language expert, Rex Harrison, to teach her to "talk more genteel." Both get more than they bargained for. The lead performances are fantastic, particularly Harrison as the exacerbating Professor Higgins, and Stanley Holloway as Alfie Doolittle, an original moralist indeed. Their charm combined with the Edith Head costumes and the wonderful Lerner/Lowe music make this film a must see.

Although many years have passed since the making of this film, wow, still seeing Audrey Hepburn really makes a person happy, especially her laughing and singing, it was a good film in all respects, today cinema has very few of these films.

I gave it a 5 (instead of 4 or even 3) because of the high quality singing, the beautiful sets and costumes, elaborate choreography, and the impressively large cast (lots of extras).Here are my problems with it:the plot drags on endlessly. I was never entertained and gave up halfway through.i find a lot of the plot points to not be believable. For example: Eliza makes a lot of mistakes in her speaking lessons that I don't think a normal, reasonably intelligent person would make when trying to match someone else's speech.in one scene where Eliza is trying to make natural conversation with other fancy British people, she whips out one of her speaking exercise phrases -- "in spain the rain falls mainly on the plain" -- which makes no sense to me. Why would she have made such a mistake? I don't find this, and many other plot points in the first half of the movie alone, to be believable at all.Eliza moves TOO gracefully and sings too well (after the first song, because Hepburn had the singing dubbed in every song after the first one) to be a Cockney girl.in each song (at least in the first half) the characters have not changed their mind or felt any different by the end. The events contained in the song do not change their mind, and my understanding is that in musical theater, if a song exists in the lineup, it should serve to move the plot forward or, very occasionally, explain the character's wants / desires / feelings to the audience. It seems like all the plot moving is done outside of the songs, which makes all of them (there's a lot of songs) extremely boring and painful.

As I watched this marvellous musical again after a period of years, I was struck by the fact of how stagebound it is. Despite the lavish sets and costumes and the fine cinematography, it is essentially the same show as on the stage. There are no exterior shots everything is filmed in the studio, scenes are set up in a very theatrical manner. Everything is nice and clean, the streets seem empty and rather unreal.Yet despite this, it all works. One gets caught up in it. This is due to the performances of the principals, Rex Harrison (wonderful!) Wilfred Hyde-White (Never better) Stanley Holloway and the Fair Lady herself Audrey Hepburn ( despite her dodgy accents), George Cukors fine direction (keeping a firm hand on things, but letting it speak for itself), Lerner and Lowes wonderful music and the witty script.As is always said they don't make them like this any more, and how could they now? Who could play them as well? A true classic.

reviews.review_title: My Fair Lady had some great supporting actors.
reviews.content: Jeremy Brett stole the show with his performance as Freddy Ensyford-Hill. Brett played the part so well.  I loved it when he snickered at Eliza Doolittle.  No one could play his part better.

reviews.review_title: Why is "my fair lady" so Good?
reviews.content: Why is "my fair lady" so Good? One Word - Charisma.

My only regret is that Julie Andrews wasn't chosen for the role of Eliza. I fell in love with this show listening to the record of the original Broadway cast when I was a young boy. Otherwise, the movie is a perfect adaptation of one of the best musicals ever written.

reviews.review_title: A few text slipups slightly mar an otherwise excellent libretto
reviews.content: The actual song texts are unbelievable and incredibly inventive.  And how amazingly Shaw- like they sound-one almost starts to believe that they were composed by him! The intricacy of rhyme is only betrayed now and then by the fact that the librettist is an American english speaker-notably in "On the Street Where You Live" we are made to believe that an englishman would rhyme "they don't bother me" with "I would rather be".  "Bother" and "rather" do not rhyme!  Also in another song a reference to "June and Fall".  Fall is I think a totally American expression for Autumn. Stanley Holloway does not manage a faultless cockney accent either as his rolling "r" is completely wrong.  A cockney r is more like a vowel. This is though still the best musical film ever followed closely by Oliver and West Side Story! Superb!

The other kind of LOVEI won't say that this is a HIGHLY enjoyable film. This is a MUSICAL!!!! And there are some-almost many- times when it seems that the SONGS are extending way too long Same lyrics being repeated again and again.. makes some scenes completely annoying. The uncaring father's Part too gets a bit too elongated and Boring.And with all that put aside this MOVIE is GREAT indeed The SONGS are also very good enjoyable The first two songs sung by the Professor and the Rag-girl are highly enjoyable.. The story is well handled The first half is a bit too longand the second half is filled with so many GREAT moments making it seem almost too short.The performances and the Chemistry between the TWO leading ACTORs is MagicalThis is Not a romantic Love Comedy. But it is a LOVE comedy Musical.The ending scene need no parsing It's a fantastic ending to a fantastic filmDID u Like Sound Of Music??? If yes then You might LOVES this one.9/10 Truly Magnificent Classic

Although this movie makes it into my top ten musicals, it isn't because of Audrey Hepburn or her acting or her lip-synching or her very bad accent. I'm not one to bemoan what could have been, but, as mentioned previously, Julie Andrews would have made this film into a thing of perfection instead of something that almost was.  Rex Harrison wanted Andrews cast instead of Hepburn, leaving me to wonder if the chemistry between he and Andrews would have been more intense and thus more credible.  Further, also as mentioned previously, the original London cast recordings demonstrate the enthusiasm and creativity that motivated "My Fair Lady" in the early days...enthusiasm and creativity that seemed to wane a bit by the time the movie rolled around (possibly a result of the mis-cast leading lady).I will say that the movie, while not a perfect thing, is a perfectly good thing.  Rex Harrison carries the film very well, and is well-balanced by strong supporting actors.  Further, the set design is flawless and the costumes are exquisite.  Finally, Audrey Hepburn doesn't ruin the movie, and is actually, to be honest, sometimes quite charming in Julie Andrew's shadow.

first saw this film when I was nine years old, after receiving it as a birthday present from my mother. For months I watched the movie on an almost daily basis, and, to everyone's surprise, surpassed "The Sound of Music" as my favorite movie (that was my daily movie when I was eight, lol). To this day I watch this movie more frequently than any other. Now that I am a bit older.. I notice that is does have quite a few flaws. It doesn't really capture the essence of Shaw's Pygmalion, but I don't think that should really take away from the movie; they should be treated as separate entities. Some of the sets are a little, well, cramped, but consider what they had to work with, they did a pretty good job. And then there is the dubbing issue. I recently special on MFL on AMC, and they showed "Wouldn't It Be Loverly" and "Show Me" with Audrey's voice, and though Audrey may not have the perfect melodic voice of Marni Nixon, her voice was much more "Eliza". I really do think they should have just used her voice. If you watch "Funny Face", you get a good feel for voice, which I think is beautiful in a unconventional way. Then, there is the question of whether Julie Andrews should have played Eliza in the film version of MFL. I've gone back and forth on this issue. Now, Audrey Hepburn is my favorite actress of all time, and Julie Andrews my second favorite, so it really is hard to "choose". Of course Julie's voice is much better than even Marni Nixon's... but like I said before, I don't think a perfect singing voice really would suit Eliza. And as for which would play a better Eliza overall.. I really don't know. I wasn't alive to see MFL on Broadway, so I really can't compare the two. What I do know is that Audrey gave an amazing performance. I really can't imagine Julie's instead of Audrey's face gazing into space right before "I could have danced all night". Anyway, as someone else said, if Julie had played Eliza, who would have played Mary Poppins? Not having Julie as Mary Poppins would be a MUCH greater tragedy than never seeing what sort of Eliza she would make on film.

Rex Harrison is perfect.  What else can one say?  He does a great job.Audrey Hepburn also is fantastic.  She has the grace and dignity befitting a princess, but in the beginning she is convincing as a lower class "gutter snipe".  I think her performance was better than Julie Andrew in Mary Poppins(which won Andrews the Oscar over Hepburn) and I think she is likely also better than Andrews was in this role.The movie moves along nicely.  It isn't fast, but it is never slow.  The dialogue is witty (listen carefully.  Higgins uses wonderful language) the plot is fun.  It is "loverly"!

Normally, I'm not one for musicals, save for the ones I remember as a kid (Mary Poppins, Willy Wonka, etc.). But as I was flipping around the dial yesterday afternoon, I stopped on AMC and started watching this. I was hooked... Harrison and Hepburn make a wonderful pair, the dialogue's witty and there's a good chance you'll have a song or two stuck in your head afterwards. It's well worth the three hours of your time.

reviews.review_title: I hate that I like this movie
reviews.content: When I was in middle school, I was in choir class.  When we had a substitute, we watched musicals.  I've seen them all.  "Oklahoma", "The Sound of Music", "Mary Poppins" and "My Fair Lady".  Of these classics, the only one I actually remember and like 13 years later is "My Fair Lady".  I don't know if it's because I've seen it a dozen times or because Eliza is so pretty and likeable or because Henry's change before your very eyes is so dramatic.  Whatever the reason, I love this movie, and it's the only movie made before I was born that I particularly enjoy.

My Fair Lady is an unlikely musical of beloved songs and characters. Romance, refreshing comedy, and unexpected satire weave through this wonderful film that retains a great deal of George Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion" (1912) which was itself inspired by Ovid's Metamorphosis. Even though it is one of the most loved romances, no one ever gets kissed. No nudity, no sex, not even a declaration of love. The story celebrates not romance but intelligence. The story involves a meeting of two egos outside a lavish London theater: linguist Henry Higgins (Rex Harrison) and flower girl Eliza Doolittle (Audrey Hepburn). Eliza is a common Cockney flower girl who is plucked from the Covent Garden and transformed into a "lady" by Higgins.It is difficult to discuss George Cukor's 1964 film as it actually exists because of the gossip that muddles it greatness. Many viewers would rather discuss the film that was not made, the one that would have starred Julie Andrews who made the role of Eliza her own on the stage. Casting Audrey Hepburn was an insult to a then little-known Andrews because the studio head Jack L. Warner chose Hepburn for her greater box appeal. Furthermore, Hepburn did not sing her own songs but was instead dubbed by the talented Marni Nixon. This dubbing became quite notorious, so much so that although My Fair Lady was nominated for twelve Oscars and won eight, Hepburn was not even nominated for best actress. Ironically, Andrews won the Best Actress Award for "Mary Poppins," while Hepburn was snubbed by the Academy.Let us step back and take another look at the controversy. Indeed, Hepburn did not sing her own songs. However, the dubbing of singing voices was very common at the time, and Nixon herself dubbed other actresses such as Deborah Kerr and Natalie Wood. Even actors who did sing their own songs lip-synced to their own pre-recorded dubs. The fact that Hepburn did not do her own singing only makes her success, which is that she did her own acting. What Hepburn did for the role was to make you care about Eliza and to believe in her transformation. Even if she did not sing her part, Hepburn still delivered a dazzling performance because of her ability to make us believe. My Fair Lady drew its dialogue from Shaw's "Pygmalion," which is more challenging than most other musicals. The dialogue was not only embedded with well-honed wit and satire but required Eliza to transition accents from Cockney to the Queen's English. Hepburn does this with flawless technique and confidence in a performance with palpable passion. The audience is given reasons to care about her character. We can relate to her, feel for what happens to her, and rejoice when things go her way. Throughout the film, Hepburn, who is so tenderly waiflike, brings a poignancy to her scenes that is magical.Not only does My Fair Lady feature an involving story with compelling characters, but there is not a dud to be found on the list of more than a dozen toe-tapping numbers. The best-known song from the film, "I Could Have Danced All Night," is familiar to almost everyone – even though who have not seen the movie. This is a testament to the brilliant marriage of dialogue and lyric in the film as seen in a poor smitten character named Freddy. Many people despise musicals because of the preposterous way characters pause mid-sentence and suddenly burst into song. Freddy avoids these predictable scenes, singing "On the Street Where You Live" with a childlike candor compared with other more emotional characters.Apart from the marvels of its words and music, My Fair Lady is a visual triumph laced with elegance. Cukor made exquisite use of Cecil Beaton who designed the production, the sets, and the costumes. Many extras are dressed in whites, blacks, and greys, creating a backdrop for Higgins in his brown tweed suit and Eliza, who has a touch of red in her dress. The story expresses endless optimism through the décor of Higgins' home, which is packed with the latest mechanical gadgets for teaching people how to speak better. The unusually remote camera stays well back from the action with relatively few close-ups, allowing the audience to see as much of the luxurious sets as possible. The audience can unmistakably see that this is a movie into which a world of care and effort was invested.What distinguished My Fair Lady above all is that it actually says something meaningful. In a film of quick words, unforgettable music, and outstanding images, it analyzes the socialist attack on the British class system. By dramatizing how superiority and success was inherited, not earned, through Eliza's escape from the lower class system, My Fair Lady becomes a great entertainment as well as a great influence. The impact it had on the creation of feminism and class- consciousness through the mid-1900s is still not sufficiently appreciated. It was a revolutionary message in England at the time, and it is still thought-provoking. Not only do people not make movies like this anymore – they simply cannot. The movie industry seems to no longer be interested in musicals about adults, much less adults with ideas. Few film genres are as magical as musicals, and few musicals are as intelligent and joyous as My Fair Lady. It is both notable and marvelous that the film stays so true to the original material and does not cave in to a schmaltzy rewritten happy ending. It remains an open question to the audience whether Eliza stays to listen to what he says next. If these two are ever to fall in love, it will be with their heads, instead of their hearts. This movie is a classic not because a group of film experts have labeled it as such, but because it has been, and always will be, a pure joy to watch.
Extremely enjoyable almost like being in the theatre but with the slickness of the big screen.

reviews.review_title: Charming and Fun, but Brace Yourself for a Lengthy Journey
reviews.content: My Fair Lady" (1964) is the epitome of a classic musical - a charming and fun romp with a handful of unforgettable numbers. Audrey Hepburn and Rex Harrison are simply divine, bringing the tale of Eliza Doolittle and Professor Henry Higgins to life with aplomb. If you love musicals, you'll swoon over the sets, the costumes, and the catchy tunes. "I Could Have Danced All Night" and "The Rain in Spain"? Iconic.But here's the thing - this movie is long. Like, marathon-length long. If you're someone who struggles to sit still for more than 15 minutes, you might want to pack a snack and a cushion. The story, while charming, isn't exactly action-packed, and some of the musical numbers feel like they go on forever. And don't even get us started on the running time - it's over 170 minutes of pure musical magic. So, buckle up and be prepared for a leisurely journey.In conclusion, "My Fair Lady" is a classic for a reason. It's full of all the charm and fun you could want from a musical, but be warned, it's a bit of a slow burn. So, grab a glass of sherry, put your feet up, and enjoy the ride!

In my opinion, when I saw a clip of Andrews playing Eliza it was just an insult to the art of acting. Eliza is a wonderful character not to be played by that of an actress who won a award for playing a nanny who flies on an umbrella. That award went to her because the crtitics must have felt sorry for her loss of a good role which really she didn't deserve. All the cast members in the film were superb and the storyline couldn't be better.

For me the film perfectly captures the greatness of one of the greatest musicals of all time. Obviously the quality of the songs both musically and lyrically are at the heart the film and what makes it one of the enduring classics. The performances are also memorable. I saw this movie when I was very young and even then remember the controversy about Audrey Hepburn getting the lead as Eliza. I find her totally captivating in this role, as I did when I first saw the movie as a young boy. I  recently learned that she received extensive coaching from the director, who was considered one of the greatest "directors of women." I find the end result to be totally successful, and I remember being almost shocked by the cockney accent and "crudeness" of her character in the first scenes when I first saw this film years ago. Although I realize I was influenced by my lack of knowledge and experience at the age at which I first saw the film, I still stand by my opinion that Hepburn does an outstanding job here and I believe it extremely likely that the greatness of the film would have been diminished if she had not been in the movie.

reviews.review_title: A very happy film. Audrey Hepburn was amazing.
reviews.content: My Fair Lady is a film filled with joy and fun and laughter. It's an easy movie to watch with family and fall in love with.The actors, particularly Audrey Hepburn, were fantastic. I do not agree that Julie Andrews could've done the role better. Andrews is indeed also a very talented actress, and a better singer, but Hepburn was perfectly - and I mean PERFECTLY qualified for acting Eliza just as well, if not a bit better.Rex Harrison also played Henry Higgins wonderfully. His English was impeccable, and his character was entertaining. Some of his dialogues were offensive, but this was simply to portray how he evolved.The film did drag on a bit, due to having so many songs. After first watching it, I had a negative opinion because I felt the story wasn't very complex. However, when I went back and couldn't help but rewatch many of its amazing songs and scenes, I realized how magical it all was. The perfect mix of direction, drama and acting has made it one of the greatest films of all time.

I had never seen this movie before. So knowing how much I love movie musicals I was given the DVD for my birthday by my brother.
