At first I didn't really enjoy it, I found it to long and a bit boring in parts and I didn't get the ending although I was suprised by how many of the songs I was familiar with. It was only after the third time of watching it that I really enjoyed it. The only thing that lets it down is it's length and Audrey's cockney accent its almost as bad as Dick Van Dyke in Mary Poppins speaking of which, I can't help but think Julie would have done a better job as Eliza. Having seen in her in The Sound of Music, she's is a fine actress as well as an excellent singer no need for any dubbing. But thats in the past.One the whole a good entertaining movie. Not one of my favourite musicals ever but its worth a look although It may take you a few views to enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: Wonderful. One of the best classic musicals.
reviews.content: I've grown to love the U. S. Hollywood movies from the 1930's-1960's. This one touches on something todays society struggles to relate to. They see something offensive when in reality the movie was, for its intense audience something of beauty and yet the complexity of relationships and that not all are textbook but rather quite often unique and beautiful in its uniqueness.I was fortunate to see this movie when it was introduced and watched how men an women laughed themselves into tears and walked away from the theater having fallen in love with almost all of the characters.

reviews.review_title: As Close to Perfection as is Humanly Possible!
reviews.content: I saw this movie last week for what was at least the twelfth time and I was reminded once again why this is my all-time favorite movie.  Was Audrey Hepburn ever more wonderful than in her role as Eliza?  And Rex Harrison-it's hard to believe that when casting was being done for the movie, Rex was not the first choice as Professor Henry Higgins. And all the supporting cast-nothing short of superb. The acting, the music, the costumes, the staging, the story-oh this movie is a perfect 10 in every way. I am sure I will never tire of watching it!

Definitely one of the best movie musicals of all time, and it's so remarkable to see how very closely it follows the stage version - there are virtually no changes at all - unlike other film adaptations where lots of things are cut etc. And it's so thrilling to have Rex Harrison and Stanley Holloway, who created the roles of Prof. Higgins and Alfred Doolittle on Broadway. They're both at their best here. Has anyone noticed how *effortless* & natural everything appears to be, for Rex? Undoubtedly because he had played Henry time & again, over the past 8 years. And now we come to the Julie vs Audrey/Marni argument. I've heard Julie Andrews on both the OBC and the OLC, and despite how great & memorable she was, Audrey Hepburn absolutely captured & made the role of Eliza Doolittle hers. She *is* Eliza to me. I disagree with everyone who says that Ms. Andrews was wrongfully robbed of her stage role, in the film. In fact, it is Audrey Hepburn who was horribly deprived of being Oscar nominated. As for Marni Nixon, she does a *REALLY* great & wonderful job with Eliza's songs, and I like her interpretation of Eliza's songs alot more than Julie Andrews' - especially "I Could Have Danced All Night" "Show Me" and even "The Rain In Spain". And I really don't believe that the dubbing is obvious in the show at 'all' - So what if there's a transition between Audrey's and Marni's voices? It's *absolutely* possible for someone to have a high soprano singing voice, and a lower ordinary voice(For instance, I'm really a baritone, but I can sing soprano just as well). Also, Audrey's *priceless* facial expressions during the songs, match Marni's singing 'perfectly' and wonderfully. So I really don't think that Julie Andrews should have done this instead of Audrey - because Ms. Hepburn was so incredible.Oh, and BTW, the imdb trivia page states that Rex Harrisson wanted Julie Andrews instead of Audrey. But did you know that when rehearsals for the Original Broadway Production began, Rex had hated Ms. Andrews for her lack of experience(although he obviously loved her later...just like the Higgins/Eliza relationship)...and that in a later interview, Rex had mentioned Ms. Hepburn as his favourite female co-star?

This is an amazing classic movie starring Audrey Hepburn. It is very well directed, with a good storyline and actors. This story is based on a play from 1913 about a regular working-class girl who is transferred into looking of high-society by a man who claims he can teach anyone to be proper.since it was made in the 1960s the film production isn't as good as it could be now.but for that time and the resources they had, they made the movie very well.this movie could also teach girl how to become proper young ladies.all and all, I would definitely recommend this movie for all ages.

reviews.review_title: An excellent and informing review! Read it!
reviews.content: "My Fair Lady" is about a young woman in London in the early 1900s. She sells flowers in the streets, dresses very shabbily, and talks with a horrible cockney accent. (Eliza Doolittle, played in the movie by Audrey Hepburn, but when it first came out on Broadway, it was played by Julie Andrews- Julie was Maria in The Sound of Music and the Queen in The Princess Diaries.) One evening, after a ball, a professor of English, Henry Higgins, hears her talking and (after singing one of the many songs about how "The French speak French, the Greek are taught their Greek, so why can't the English learn to speak?") wagers with his friend that he can pass her off as a lady in a florist shop, or a Duchess at the Embassey ball, by teaching her to speak proper British. Henry Higgins is played by Rex Harrison, who starred in the first movie version of Dr. Doolittle. So Higgins takes her into his home and dresses her properly and tries to teach her a good accent. It's very funny, for some of the many things in the movie: before the ball, they take Eliza to the Ascot races, and although she speaks with a faked proper accent, she has terrible grammar, and she says things like how after her Aunt died -from too much rum- someone "pinched" her new straw hat that was to have been willed to her- and all of Professor Higgins's friends think her conversation is perfectly charming and the latest fashion, Higgins is mortified, of course. And then, in the middle of the race, everyone is perfectly quiet and elegant watching the horses, and no one says a word. Except for Eliza, who shouts out, "come on, Dover, move your blooming a*r*s*e !" and then some of the fine ladies faint. :) They take her to the ball in the most stunning dress ever, she doesn't do anything wrong at all, the Queen stops in the middle of the procession down the hall to tell her she's perfectly charming, and the prince dances with her!!! He's so handsome! :) When they come home after the ball, she starts crying because she realizes -what is she going to do now? She can't live with Henry Higgins once her training is complete, think how the neighbors would gossip! :) And she can't work in a "florist shop" as Higgins said at first now, because she has become so fine and people would recognize her- although it is more respectable to work in a fine florist shop than to sell flower bunches in the street, it is a position less than a lady who doesn't have to work and goes to balls with princes. But it has a happy ending- although not said, it is intimated at the very last, despite Higgins singing two songs about how terrible and unorganized women are, and how he would never marry, that they get married and live happily ever after. The End. :) It's a lovely cute movie, it's happy, and has some of the most famous songs in it. Here's some clips of it, listen to them!http://www.amazon.com/exec /obidos/tg/detail/-/B000002 AW2/qid=1125605575/sr=2-1/r ef=pd_bbs_b_2_1/002-4008246-2626449?v=glance&s=musicYou'll like them, and it will make you want to watch the movie.

Audrey Hepburn is simply stunning in this movie - as in most. Only drag is that she did not actually sing her songs in the movie. Also, the poor quality of the majority of songs is quite disappointing.The story is just superb, though. But who is to thank for that?Anyways, I give it a 7/10 because of the very solid overall cast, some quite remembering songs - by far the most outstanding of them being "I Could Have Danced All Night" -, the thought out lead characters (but actually only them, since the supporting roles were rather shallow. At least the part of Pickering could be exhausted in a more interesting way, although it is hinted at at the end of the movie).

This is one of the most delightful movies ever made. But I enjoyed the story plot better than the songs. Don't get me wrong, the music is wonderful. Just love the story a whole lot better. To me, it was perfectly cast. Although, with my first viewing of it, I didn't much care for the character of Eliza's father. Then after watching the film a couple of times, he began to grow on me. Who can resist humming along with "With Just a Little Bit of Luck"?***SPOILER ALERT***Just recently I heard that there was an alternate ending somewhere that has Eliza ending up with Freddie. Goodness gracious, why?? To me, his infatuation for her is something like a lovesick puppy. It's obvious who Eliza loves -- Prof. Higgins. And Prof. Higgins loves her. This is evident at Henry's mother's house (Mrs. Higgins is also a treasure). Love the original ending where Eliza comes back to the Professor's house.

This is one of the great musicals of all time. Audrey Hepburn is nothing short of brilliant as Eliza. Wish this would come around on one of those big-screen events, I would pay to see it in the theater.

I brought the movie 'My Fair Lady' and I loved it!! It is a great movie for everyone to see of all ages.The movie itself is about a poor flower girl who lives on the street. A professor sees her and his friend makes a bet with him that he will turn her into a proper lady in 6 months and he would Pay for all expense. So Eliza moves in with them and begins her lessons. She learns how to walk, talk and dress like a Lady. However she finds herself falling in love with Professer Higgans. When the six months is up, she runs away thinking that Higgans doesn't care about her at all since hes won his bet. In the end, she returns to him.I think the only thing lacking in the other wise 10 star story is a proper ending. The last part of this movie is the only part that needs a bit more. I think that it would've been better if they had Eliza and Professer Higgans Marrige. I also thought it needed more romance. The most romantic part of the story is when They dance together at the ball.Still, the movie is a great watch for anyone, with the perfect music and wardrobe. I think it is a great Movie for anyone. And this movie will live on for many more years.

I think this movie is unnecessarily long and the main reason of that is the fact that it is a musical movie. The harmony between songs sung by the characters and narrative of movie is so successful. But the movie is so constant and has a simple story for a 3-hour-movie. Performance of actors and actresses were perfect. In the movie, her success in becoming a lady is so effectively in terms that it shows us that if you want to do anything or have any feature and if you work enough and be passionate to receive what you want, you will receive. Although I was a bit bored, it was a pleasure to watch this movie and grab the messages to apply on my life. I cannot say I totally advice this movie; however, the old is like the gold. I mean even if years and years pass by, although many things get worthless, both the gold and the old classics do not.
